output: Mr. President, first of all, I would like to congratulate Mr. Siebeck on the work done, as his report incorporates many of the concerns expressed in this…

The camera focuses on these crucial issues for the entire European Union. These are water scarcity and drought, matters that have already ceased to be solely a problem for the countries of Southern Europe.

I am pleased that this project incorporates some of the reflections outlined in the opinion report, of which I was rapporteur in the Agriculture Committee, advocating for agricultural activity, and highlighting, for example, the role that farmers play in the sustainable management of available resources.

It also includes a reference to drought and water scarcity as factors that exacerbate commodity prices, a point that, in these times, I also believe it is very important to highlight, so that we keep in mind not only the environmental dimension of this problem, but also some of its most relevant economic consequences.

The Environment Committee also included the idea of creating a European Drought Observatory, an action itself mentioned in the Agriculture Committee’s report, and which I hope will one day be reflected in concrete actions.

The text to be voted on tomorrow, however, does not include a proposal made by the Agricultural Commission to study the implementation of an economic adaptation fund against drought, a fund that would benefit all economic sectors, including agriculture.

For my part, I would like to make it clear that I will continue defending the establishment of this fund, an idea that I will again propose to Parliament when, in the coming months, the Commission publishes its communication on adaptation to climate change.

It seems to me that after the Solidarity Fund was established—originally created to mitigate losses caused by climate disasters—it is time to consider an instrument that acts proactively and is intended to finance preventative measures to reduce the environmental and economic costs of those climatic catastrophes.
Atlético Madrid, its fans, and even the Spanish police are being mistreated by the European Football Federation.
However, the case extends beyond the particular, as those federal bodies increase the penalties for those who resort to the ordinary justice system.
This medieval conception, this bottleneck effect, is incompatible with the law, with European institutions, from which we must react.

And we will inevitably bring it about, for those medieval lords, arbitrary wielders of the rope and dagger, must align themselves with respect for the law and the ordinary procedural guarantees of our Europe.
Mr. President, Commissioner, terrorism is a global phenomenon, and so is the activity of serious organized crime; therefore, measures must be proportionate and must be fought effectively.

I have taken good note of the responses given to the pertinent questions. It is true that guarantees must be demanded, it is true that it is a delicate matter, but it is no less certain that it is absolutely inexcusable to assemble, to form a globalized and harmonized response.
For some, terrorism seems a little distant; they are more concerned with individual guarantees.
I am concerned with both individual and collective matters, and it is absolutely necessary that we begin where we can.
If we have started with air transport, where companies already possess that data, let's begin there.

Let us demand guarantees, let's see what the scope of application is, let's begin with the relationships of international transport and, be careful, we will have to continue with the domestic ones because terrorists often do not come from outside, but come from within.
Let the United States be asked, and let the others be asked as well; this is the reality, and this is how we must frame it.
Mr. President, I would like to thank the Commission for presenting this proposal.
I believe it is a positive proposal that will help us reduce unnecessary administrative burdens.
Now, as speakers preceding me have pointed out, this Parliament has the obligation to ground proposals that are very generous and very altruistic on the part of the Commission.

The reality is that there is a national reality encompassing twenty-seven countries with different legal systems and vastly different languages, which requires that in each of those countries we adapt to the realities of the country, including the matter of languages.

Specifically, as Gosset has just pointed out and as previous speakers have indicated, it is important that the recognition of these national specializations does not lead to increased costs, that rates are uniform, and that governments ultimately assume this additional cost.
But there is a topic that also arises, and that is the topic of translations.
Specifically, in the European Union we do not have a common language.
In the twenty-seven countries, vastly different languages are commonly spoken; indeed, in some countries, such as the commissioner’s, multiple languages are spoken, and we live with this reality.
And from a legal perspective, moreover, we encounter the reality that legal documents are different.
The Legal Commission has proposed, for example, amendments regarding the authentication of records, of documents, along with the authentication of the translation.
At this moment, the Committee on Legal Affairs is preparing a report on the recognition of authentic acts in different countries of the European Union that should be complementary to this report.
Ultimately, I believe the Commission has done well in presenting this report.
The speaker has done a magnificent job, and I believe we have all striven to draft a legislative proposal that can be recognized throughout the Union, guaranteeing human rights.
rights and starting from the foundations of the reality of a union that is being built, which has different national legal systems and different levels of access to electronic communication.

Mr. President, a large majority of farmers and ranchers are awaiting decisions and agreements that the European Union’s Council of Agriculture Ministers will adopt between today and tomorrow regarding this Union check.

the CAP, because this is not a simple revision, but will bring about profound changes, such as the disappearance of many farms, if the cut proposed by the European Commission on direct payments goes ahead.

Modulation is the central point of this parliamentary report and could be one of the few elements of the Parliament's opinion to have some impact on the negotiations being held by the Union’s Agriculture Ministers.
We have consistently opposed for years any increase in what is euphemistically called modulation, because if rural development policy does not have sufficient funds, it is...

not due to a lack of resources within the budgetary ceiling of the CAP, but rather due to an absolute absence of political will to equip the Community budget with that necessary foundational development.
Do they want to liberalize the markets?
Certainly, do so, but with equal requirements and conditions for all producers, both within and outside the Union.

At this moment, the European Union is determining the future of many farmers and livestock breeders, and I would particularly like to make reference to vulnerable sectors such as sheep, cattle, and tobacco, whose survival in many producing areas will depend on this review.

Some producers, such as those in the sheep sector, no longer request assistance, but simply want to be allowed to exit the market with dignity, because they have done the calculations and the only way to survive is to reduce production volumes.

Therefore, abandoning production is the only option we leave for many producers, whose space will undoubtedly be taken by imports from third countries, because consumers will continue to consume, and the world will continue to increase the number of consumers at a rapid pace.
Parliament should issue a measured opinion, and the Council should heed it.

I would like to express my gratitude from here to the president of the Committee on Agriculture for the efforts Mr. París has undertaken to ensure that Parliament is heard and not disrespected in such a clear and overt manner by the Council and the Commission as has been the case until now.
Mr. President, firstly, please add me to the congratulations offered by the speaker, Mr. Capulas Santos, for his magnificent work.
I believe you have found balance and moderation in your report.
I believe that at this stage of the debate, it is important to send a message of stability to our farmers.
European farmers need stability and solutions more than ever.
Sufficient transitional periods are necessary, as well as maintaining specific measures that are required for sectors experiencing difficulty.
Madam Commissioner, the same solutions do not apply to all sectors.
It is important to remember that we have sectors experiencing genuine difficulties.
The Common Agricultural Policy doesn’t need to be the problem, but the solution, and to that end, we need a strong first pillar.
We believe in and advocate for rural development, but we do not believe that the modulation proposed by the Commission is the solution.
It is not a matter of strengthening rural development at the expense of the first pillar.
We agree that the single payment system needs to be simplified, and that market instruments should be reviewed.
But that does not mean dismantling them.
If we do this well, we will be laying the groundwork for a common agricultural policy beyond 2013. If not, we will be undermining the activity of many European farmers.
We are facing a plan long awaited by the fruit and vegetable sector, not only due to the difficulties it is experiencing, but also due to the worrying decline in consumption.
We are faced with a public health promotion plan. I believe it should be a European plan and I also advocate for full community funding.

I do not agree with the inclusion of parents in co-funding, because what always happens will occur. Parents who can contribute money will have their children consume fruits and vegetables in schools, while those who cannot will be left out of the program.
I believe it has to be a community-funded plan to ensure its distribution is homogeneous.
Therefore, I also want to strongly emphasize that the focus must be on educational measures.

It’s not merely about a student eating an apple, but knowing what type of apple they are eating, understanding its nutritional properties, and comprehending the beneficial effects that fruit has on their health and development.
Of course, these must be products with all quality guarantees, prioritizing, if possible, seasonal fruits and, when feasible, I advocate for the community origin of our fruits and vegetables.

I believe that the beneficial effects of this plan, which I applaud and for which I want to congratulate the commissioner, we will notice immediately, of course, for the present and future health of our children and their education.

nutritional, but I also believe it is very important for the horticultural sector, a productive sector that constitutes a genuine European cultural heritage, as it allows us to enjoy a balanced, healthy, and varied diet.
I believe it is worthwhile to invest and commit to this plan for the distribution of fruits and vegetables in our schools.
I believe the budget falls a little short, because I reiterate my support for full Community financing of a plan as ambitious as this one.
Mr. President, I ask that you not include these first words, please, in the infernal machine of time.
My first words are to add my voice to the message of condolence expressed by this Chamber, directed towards Mrs. Klaas, and above all, to congratulate the rapporteurs.
Now, I truly begin.

I commend the speakers because with these two proposals we are taking a qualifying step toward a common immigration policy, and entering into the promotion of legal immigration, a key pillar of the global approach we advocate.
The overarching framework of rights and the single residence and work permit for legal emigrants should be extended to the greatest number of workers.
Therefore, socialists are requesting that no category of workers be excluded.
The so-called Blue Card offers an opportunity for migrants to settle with their families and work in our countries.
opens a unique door to twenty-seven labor markets.
However, through this door should not only enter highly qualified workers.
Therefore, Commissioner, we expect the Commission to present its proposals relating to the other occupational categories shortly.
Honorable members, we must fight against the brain drain.
This blue card should not become a passport that encourages the drain of vital human resources from developing countries.
Therefore, from the Socialist Group, we want to ensure that for every qualified professional who comes to Europe, we fund the training of a new professional in their country of origin.
Finally, Europe must be an attractive destination, not only for talents coming from outside the Union, but also for our own.
In 2007, nearly three hundred Europeans with high qualifications left to work outside the Union.
Let us do everything possible to keep them at the European House.
Madam Vice President, do you believe that the proximity or distance of candidates to voters is related to the level of participation in European elections?
European. Do you agree that a state of forty-five million inhabitants should have only one electoral district for elections to the European Parliament?
European, what can the Commission do to ensure that States with larger populations have constituencies closer to the citizens?
Excuse me, but I have not heard that the Vice President has responded to my questions.
Thank you very much, Madam President. You have provided me with a great deal of information on the topic I raised, and I am grateful for that detailed information.
I believe the new phase of the Commission is important, and above all, the Bamako project, of a European Union center for immigration matters.

I understand that it has just opened, that it is probably very early, but the question I pose to the Commission is, should that Bamako-Bali project on immigration yield positive results, does the Commission believe it possible to extend that experience to the rest of the countries on the southern shore of the Mediterranean?
I acknowledge the response on behalf of Mr. Yáñez, but I must tell Commissioner Michel that his actions, words, and gestures are very necessary in direct contact.
truly with the Cuban democratic opposition to fulfill the Council’s priority conclusions and reduce the effects of the terrible Castro dictatorship in favor of freedom.
Mr. President, on behalf of the Socialist Group, I wish to express my Group’s strongest condemnation of the killings being committed in this region of Somalia, invoking the name of God.
Few atrocities have been committed by someone who has not invoked the name of God or a religion.

Specifically, the manner in which this heinous murder was committed, we now know, a 13-year-old girl who is raped and subsequently accused of adultery, and who five men, if one can call them men, hasten to stone, preventing even someone from attempting to save her in a stadium occupied by a thousand people.

This, combined with the acts of piracy that this year along the coasts of Somalia have reached the level of almost one hundred ships seized, constitutes a humanitarian situation that is absolutely unacceptable.
The international community cannot remain impassive in the face of this.
It cannot remain impassive in the face of cowardice, in the face of religious invocation to commit atrocities.
Therefore, we must restore order by supporting the legitimate Government of Somalia in regaining control of the entire country and establishing a rule of law that respects human rights.
I believe that on few occasions has a situation so clear and imposing obligations been presented to us.
I do not believe that we can remain impassive here within this community of 500 million people and 27 countries, the most important in the world, without intervening in that situation.
I don't know how it will be possible, but I am certain that it must be done and that intervention is required promptly.
The Socialist Group does not agree with the amendments that have been presented at the last minute, which were not negotiated at the time.

We support the text of the joint resolution and hope that this will be the beginning of greater concern from the European Union regarding these types of humanitarian issues and the condemnation of the abusive use of religious concepts to commit atrocities in the name of God.
I believe that the speaker and the previous speakers have highlighted the characteristics of this directive proposal from the European Parliament and the Council.
It concerns the recognition that armaments and ammunition, too, are within the internal market, albeit with a series of limitations.
This is not about ordinary merchandise; these are not candies nor entertainment items, but rather objects that require precise control.
Certainly, there are limitations inherent in the Treaty itself, article thirty and article two hundred and ninety-six, which confer significant responsibilities upon States in the matter.
And the fact that we have a common market does not prevent States from being obligated to comply with safety regulations and, rightfully, to enforce them when their own security is jeopardized.

The work undertaken by the Committee on Legal Affairs and the committees providing expert opinions, in accordance with the Council, under the expert direction of the rapporteur, Ms. Ruile, has been very positive.
I believe the text we present today is a rather balanced text.

Basically, although they appear to be many amendments on paper, today we are limited to a single amendment, which is amendment 63, and it is this amendment that captures the spirit of compromise. Within that amendment, one can see a well-articulated, coherent text that will allow the functioning of this entire market.
Mr. Tubón has highlighted that this is related to other international texts.

For example, the adoption this very month of the Oslo Convention, the signing of the Oslo Convention on the prohibition of cluster munitions, also the Convention on the Limitation of Antipersonnel Mines, and a whole series of international agreements and even regulations of the European Union aimed at limiting the use of weapons.

I believe that our model is not one of the free circulation of arms at any time, but rather of a regulated market, controlled by the States and also, from now on, by the institutions of the European Union themselves.
Madam President, Commissioner, this proposal emerged from the Commission over a year ago, with truly very ambitious objectives.
During this time, financial upheavals have occurred globally that appeared to threaten these measures, but ultimately, a balanced agreement has been reached.
it does not satisfy almost anyone one hundred percent, but it is a good agreement that maintains the final objectives, while making the means to achieve them more accessible to companies.

Therefore, we must express our sincere gratitude and congratulations to the speaker, Ms. Doyle, to the speakers from the other political groups, and to the French Presidency, especially, because their work has resulted in a good outcome for all.

I am confident that in the near future, circumstances will allow us to be much more ambitious, and that other countries will also join this crusade to combat climate change that we so wish to carry out in Europe.
Mr. President, Commissioner, this was a good proposal as it emerged from the Commission, not only because of the sulfur reductions, but also because of its new Article Seven bis, which demanded a…

gradual reduction of greenhouse gas emissions and because it resolved the long-standing issue of vapor pressure for gasoline blends with bioalcohol in countries like mine, which experience warm summers.
Precisely this did not pass the filter of the vote in the Environmental Committee, and this concerned many of us.

Today we have an agreement on the table that softens the application of Article Seven bis and that reinstates the vapor pressure waiver, while, of course, tightening the conditions for accessing the exception.
and that, as in the rest of this climate package, the agreement does not satisfy everyone one hundred percent, but, nonetheless, it is acceptable to all.

I would like to thank Mrs. Corbey for her excellent work, for the receptiveness she has shown in resolving issues, as well as Mr. Turmes and, of course, the French Presidency, which has also demonstrated considerable effectiveness here.
As the report states, according to the 2007 estimates, Zimbabwe has a population of twelve million, nearly half of whom are experiencing hunger.

Life expectancy is thirty-six years, and more than forty percent of the country’s teachers are working, with only one-third of the students attending class; consequently, Mugabe is not only killing the present, he is killing the future.
The repression and mutilation of human rights are also commonplace.
Human rights defenders in Zimbabwe have been systematically targeted with arbitrary detentions, arrests, and torture.
The legislation introduced by the Government severely restricts freedom of expression, assembly, movement, and association.
I would like to cite several of them, as the Government has introduced increasingly repressive regulations, which have been used against these activist human rights defenders.

For example, the Law on Access to Information and Protection of Privacy, used by the Government to effectively silence journalists, the Public Order and Security Law, which has severely limited freedom of assembly and hundreds of…

Human rights defenders, including independent media workers, have been arbitrarily detained, as has the law on private voluntary organizations, re-established in 2002 by the Government and purportedly used to intimidate and harass NGOs.
Madam President, in my native language, Basque—Euskera, which is not an official language in this Chamber—Mugabe means without limit, a fitting epithet for this individual.

The dictator of that African country is not merely one more on the extensive list of dictators we unfortunately count on this planet, but I venture to say that he occupies one of the positions in the top ten of dictators.
I believe that in the EU, we must do everything possible to ensure this individual leaves and spends the rest of their days seated before a Human Rights Tribunal.
Therefore, we wish Zimbabwe a happy year two thousand nine without Mugabe.
We have a proposed resolution on Nicaragua in which several aspects must be considered.
First, there is an allegation of fraud, at least in two municipalities, Nicaragua and León, and this tarnishes the electoral outcome of November ninth.
On the other hand, we have a government that has been concerned with resolving some of the problems that undermine human rights in Latin America.
specifically, poverty, illiteracy, infant mortality, access to potable water, and the lack of land tenure for indigenous peoples.
Therefore, when examining the case, we must clearly distinguish the two aspects.

On one hand, we must stimulate human rights and defend human rights in the traditional sense as political rights, and on the other, we must encourage the Nicaraguan Government, continuing in its role of assistance to the most needy sectors of the country.
Of course, we must guarantee that the opposition can perform its function, we must oppose fraud, but—and we must defend the work of NGOs.
However, a balanced outcome must be achieved.
The Socialist Group has presented several proposals for oral amendments, seeking to steer the final text to make it more balanced with respect to the claims of.

violations of fundamental rights, with regard to the criminal or non-criminal nature of the investigations, and with regard to the number of municipalities in which the effect has resulted in some form of derogation.

In summary, we want to condemn the alleged violations of fundamental political rights, but without going so far as to place the Government of Nicaragua in a difficult position to continue fulfilling its role in supporting the most vulnerable segments of society.
Regarding the situation created in Nicaragua due to attacks against certain human rights defenders, against some fundamental freedoms, and against democracy.

It is unnecessary to recall here now Zoila América, nor Ernesto Cardenal, nor Carlos Mejía Godoy, nor Jarquín, nor Sergio Ramírez, nor so many other Nicaraguans who today feel betrayed in their hopes for a better Nicaragua.
In November of two thousand six, Mr. Ortega requested and obtained, democratically, from the Nicaraguan people what he termed a new opportunity.
Today, we already know what she wanted it for.
Since then, arbitrary actions, nepotism, and corruption have become entrenched within the institutions of the Government, culminating in the electoral fraud of the November ninth election.

Previously, very serious decisions had been adopted, such as the revocation of legal personality from certain opposition parties, threats and intimidation of civil society members, journalists, and media outlets.
President Ortega described the governments of the European Union as flies buzzing around filth and characterized the external aid Nicaragua received as crumbs.
He soon understood that there was not enough Venezuelan oil to forgo that development assistance.

As we prepare to enter a decisive phase in the negotiation of an association agreement between the European Union and Central America, the Government of Nicaragua should know that it will always find in us an ally and a friend.

but for us, the insistence on respect for human rights, freedom of expression, and democracy in general is a condition to which we do not relinquish, because we believe that the people of Nicaragua especially benefit from it.
On November ninth, municipal elections were held in Nicaragua.
As on previous occasions, that electoral process has been called into question from the perspective of democratic legitimacy, with accusations of fraud being made and incidents occurring...
demonstrations and clashes between supporters of different political parties, resulting in numerous injuries and a deepening of the political crisis that this country has been experiencing.
Two political parties have been unable to present themselves in the local elections, which is unacceptable because it restricts the fundamental right of all citizens to political participation.

On the other hand, we have received direct testimonies from representatives of human rights organizations who have informed us about the existence of questioning of the judicial system by civil society.

regarding the existence of administrative repression mechanisms that have brought as many as seventeen organizations of social movements before the courts, concerning the persecution of independent journalists and even the European Commission delegation.

For all these reasons, we wish to raise our voices and make an appeal, first, to political parties to condemn the acts of violence perpetrated by their followers, and second, to the government itself to reopen spaces for participation.

a citizen, who respects freedom of expression, who ceases to prohibit marches, and who allows all NGOs to receive aid from international cooperation, not only those from Venezuela, for pro-governmental associations.
Likewise, that they repeal the penalization of therapeutic abortion in cases where the mother’s life is at risk.

And finally, we also want to request that the Commission remind Nicaragua, during negotiations for the Association Agreement between Central America and the European Union, that it must respect the principles of the rule of law.

democracy and human rights, all without prejudice to our continued provision of assistance from Europe for the development and well-being of the Nicaraguan people, whom we desire to have the best possible future.
Madam President, I will be referring to the Breyer report.
I must say that European farmers are fully aware that the use of plant protection products requires particular attention to human health and also to the protection of the environment.
However, the sector is deeply concerned because the European Parliament does not understand the impact this Regulation may have on the future.

It is the case that there are assessments of its potential impact that indicate that, due to the scarce future availability of plant protection products, achieving the objective will be very difficult.
control of pests and diseases affecting the cultivation of a wide range of foods, specifically all Mediterranean products, as well as the cultivation of ornamental plants and cut flowers.
I am fully aware that the agreement adopted in the three-way dialogue has been the result of arduous negotiations and I cannot help but recognize the work done by the rapporteurs.

However, it must be taken into account that the temporal definition of endocrine disruptors will lead to the disappearance of a significant number of active substances, particularly insecticides, of key importance for agriculture.

Producers must have a sufficient quantity of active substances available to effectively and safely combat any plant disease or pest, bearing in mind that the danger often lies not in the product itself, but in its misuse.
For all these reasons, the Spanish delegation of the PPE Group of the EPP supports the proposals requesting an impact assessment and will vote in favor of the amendments.
from Mr. Stardy, which I myself have signed, relating to endocrine disruptors and those that favor the availability of plant protection products in emergency situations.

Furthermore, if this Regulation is adopted in accordance with the reached Agreement, the effects will be a reduction in food production and an increase in prices, leading us to import those very same foods that we are not producing, traded with the products that we are prohibiting.
Mr. President, Mr. Capato, your report is full of good intentions. The most evident proof of this is that it did not warrant any amendments during its processing in the Committee on Civil Liberties.
You yourself introduced eighteen amendments to your own report.
And it is those amendments that have introduced a certain degree of radicalism, so to speak, into that report—a degree that raises very serious doubts for me.
I would structure the amendments you have raised—amendments you have raised yourself, I insist—within four distinct tiers, as detailed in a report that initially received the support of all groups.
Some impossibilities. You are requesting some things that are impossible.

For example, Mr. Capato, you are requesting things for which there is no legal basis yet. For example, until the Treaty of Lisbon comes into force, it will be impossible to harmonize the regulations of different committees.
Something similar to what Commissioner Wallström just said. You ask, for example, that we declare 2009 the Year of Transparency. We are late; there is no longer any time.
Therefore, you are requesting things that are impossible.
Furthermore, he requests some others that are inadvisable.
For example, you request that there be transparency in the meetings of political groups.
No, less.
that privacy is needed. Privacy is a political good.
If I wish to dissent from my party, to maintain an opposition, I want to do so privately, and that is not a lack of transparency.
Transparency should be demanded of public bodies, but not within political parties, where debates must be guaranteed in privacy.
Therefore, I cannot follow him/her/it in that.
There are some other assessments you make, Mr. Capato, that are uncertain.
For example, you say that ninety percent of legislative activity is due to committee work.
That is a reckless exaggeration, Mr. Capato.
And, moreover, criminology inherently involves standards of transparency.

If what we are going to do now is create more mechanisms, more bureaucracy, more controls, we will be acting against what we aim to achieve, which is transparency—something that closely approaches simplicity.
Finally, before the gentleman president calls me to order, because I am already using my allotted time, there are a few things that are unnecessary.
For example, I understand that it is very tempting and highly appealing to public opinion to say transparency in the activity of the deputies, that it be known they attend the plenary sessions.
That is well known, Mr. Capato.
What goes to the committees is known to be acts accessible to all citizens.
or the diets that charge. You know, Mr. Capato.
That is to say, it is perfectly possible for a citizen to have access to that information.

Therefore, I understand that it is very appealing to public opinion and that it greatly enhances one’s standing to defend transparency, but I want you to know that transparency is about making things appear as they are. And when one contributes to obscuring the truth, Mr. Capato, then we are not contributing to transparency.
Thank you for your generosity, Mr. President.
I watch the situation in Gaza with horror, pain, and shame, but also with a commitment to defending peace and those who suffer most, and to upholding dignity and hope.
horror at the repeated scene of children murdered and women torn apart in their endless suffering following the bombings of the ghetto in which Gaza has become.
The same horror that Picasso depicted in his Guernica, our Guernica devastated by Junker’s Legion Condor seven decades ago.
compassionate grief for so many victims of so much suffering.
and shame for the inability of all—of our States, of the European Union, and of the international community—first to prevent and then to end the criminal aggression we have denounced.
Shame and indignation at so much falsehood, so much ambiguity, and so much empty rhetoric.
Shame because we know exactly what is happening and do not act with the necessary and required forcefulness and coherence.
Therefore, history will hold many accountable as accomplices to the crime, if only by omission.
Because it is better late than never and because it is essential to keep a door open to hope, the European Union must support the late resolution of the Security Council.

to ensure it is fulfilled rigorously, just as our Association Agreement with Israel must be rigorously fulfilled, which stipulates its suspension in the face of conduct such as that which is occurring.
By the way, it is never also responsible for the media blackout that I have yet to hear anyone denounce.

We must state with clear and unequivocal firmness to Israel that it must cease killing, allow the wounded to be healed, and provide sustenance to those affected, and that its attitude toward international law must have consequences in its relations with Europe.
I wish to greet the few European volunteer young people who are suffering alongside the people of Gaza, in particular Alberto Arce.
They represent the best of the values of solidarity and freedom of this our Europe, which must be consistent in this terrible conflict.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, as we can see, in recent times the textile sector has been experiencing a significant crisis, leading to numerous business closures, relocations, and unemployment—events that are concentrated precisely in regions specialized in this activity.

Given this current economic juncture of crisis, the European Commission should act swiftly alongside the Member States to mitigate the socioeconomic effects of this restructuring, particularly dramatic for the affected territories and families.

I believe it is necessary to provide assistance to workers in the textile and garment sector with social measures, with plans for companies that are undergoing restructuring and currently facing serious difficulties.
It would be desirable to allocate a substantial portion of the Globalization Adjustment Fund to the restructuring and retraining of the textile sector.
particularly concerning small and medium-sized enterprises, which predominantly comprise the sector in the European Union and are disproportionately affected by market liberalization.
On the other hand, it is necessary to reinstate the system of control over imports from abroad and, especially, those from China due to their volume.
It is not about promoting trade barriers at all.

It is a matter of offsetting the negative effects of such a significant transformation. And we must not forget that the European Union is the world’s second-largest exporter of textile products and garments.

That is to say, which makes it necessary to guarantee the best possible access conditions to third-country markets, essential for the future of the textile and apparel industry based in the European Union and, in particular, for SMEs.
All of this, of course, guaranteeing fair competition based on the promotion of environmental and social standards in these countries.

In this regard, the publication of accurate information to the consumer, for example, with the regulation on the “Made in” indication, which, as far as we know, has not been implemented, would be of great utility since.
Among other things, it would involve subjecting imported products to the same safety and consumer protection requirements as those manufactured within the European Union.
Mr. Romeva, the Spanish Government need not worry; it will cooperate as it always has.

I remind you that in this matter, the Spanish Minister of Foreign Affairs, Miguel Ángel Moratinos, was the first to appear before the Investigative Commission and the one who answered all the questions, including their own.

This. From this Chamber, we have long been denouncing the torture and inhuman and degrading treatment occurring at the Guantánamo Bay military base in the name of the fight against international terrorism.
Therefore, we applaud Obama's decision to suspend trials for four months and his objective of permanently closing the prison within a year.
However, although responsibility rests with the United States government, the Union cannot turn a blind eye and must offer its collaboration to achieve the closure of the detention center.
We should also consider the possibility of accepting prisoners originating from countries where human rights are not guaranteed, should the United States not request it.

Then we will have to provide a common European response, in which the Spanish Government will participate, respecting the international legal framework and the case-by-case analysis of the legal situation of each citizen, each detainee, their origin and detention, and their circumstances.

Mr. President, within the EU, there are various cases of languages intrinsic to historical European peoples that, due to not being constituted as states, are not permitted to be used in the debates of this Parliament, and this constitutes a democratic and representative deficit.

One such case is that of the Basque language, Euskera, which is not a minority language, but an official one, at least in the southern part of the Basque Country, which administratively falls within the Spanish State.

But the same does not occur, and please do not take this personally, Commissioner, regarding the Basque Country, which is incorporated into the French State, whose president, before the Assembly of the United Nations, affirms that denying respect to national identities and languages fuels humiliation, and that without that respect, there will be no peace in the world.
And then, neither Basque, nor Corsican, Breton, or Occitan receive the slightest official consideration, nor do they benefit from support to respect or foster their use.

Therefore, I request that the Agency for Fundamental Rights monitor and work to ensure that within the Member States, the rights of no European people's mother tongue are violated, nor are their inhabitants discriminated against, and that all of them are considered official within their respective territories.
Skerry Casco, Jan Andreok, Suel Laguncha Gaitik, Europa Co. and Skuncha Agustín Alde.

Madam President, first, I would like to thank our rapporteur, Claudio Fava, for his excellent work in reaching a common position with the Council, which incorporates many improvements proposed by our Parliament.
With this Directive, we demonstrate once again our commitment to building a common migration policy based on a global approach.
The aim of this Directive is clear: to combat organized crime, punish unscrupulous employers, and protect exploited immigrants who lack any form of social protection.

We want the unjust, meager wages paid to immigrants to disappear, and furthermore, to cease distorting average salaries, particularly in sectors such as construction, agriculture, domestic service, or hospitality.
These measures require considerable courage and political will, as there are many vested interests and significant sums of money involved in the shadow economy.
Precisely in times of difficulty, it is more important than ever to manage migratory flows with intelligence, with generosity but with responsibility.
It would be easy to succumb to the temptation of not attempting to curtail the shadow economy.
We cannot turn a blind eye and leave approximately eight million undocumented immigrants in a state of defenselessness, facing working conditions akin to slavery.

Honorable members, if we want this Directive to be effective, rigorous inspections and economic, and even criminal, sanctions in the most aggravated cases are necessary—sanctions that will have a deterrent effect on business owners.
We will thus reduce the pool of undeclared economic activity and curtail the incentive for migration generated by the possibility of irregular employment.
It must be made clear that the only option for working in Europe is through legal channels.

Therefore, we wish to continue with the global approach and ask the Commission, Commissioner, Mr. Baró, to present the new Blue Cards, quotation marks, for the other occupational categories as soon as possible.
Esteemed colleagues, Mrs. Ferrero-Waldner, Mr. Solana, I would first like to thank the three rapporteurs for their work. As shadow rapporteur for the report on CFSP, I will refer to
With regard to this report specifically, beginning by congratulating Mr. Saris Volski on the outcome of his work and on the collaboration offered by the other groups to achieve a consensus result.

Just as this Parliament has repeatedly called for the European Union to be equipped with the necessary instruments to speak with a single voice in the world, so too does this Chamber demonstrate its cohesion in evaluating and promoting major priorities in foreign policy and common security.

Our group, the Socialist Group, has pursued a twofold direction: on the one hand, to introduce or reinforce key issues for us, transversally across all foreign policy, such as the fight against climate change, the promotion of…

peace across the entire planet or a wager on human development. On the other hand, suggesting elements of rebalancing between the geographical priorities of the Common Foreign and Security Policy (CFSP) with respect to how they originally appeared in the text, if they appeared at all, or introducing them as a new element if they were absent.
In this way, we have advocated, for example, for greater clarification of the relationships between the institutional and cooperation frameworks involved in the eastern dimension, recently defined.

We have advocated for greater diversification and increased relevance in our relations with Africa, a continent of which we often only remember when wars of particular virulence occur, and often not even then.

Regarding Latin America, we have sought to reflect the current processes of negotiating association agreements, the first of a bilateral nature that the European Union will conclude throughout its history.

Regarding the Mediterranean, we have opposed a reductionist approach that only speaks of security, to instead include the rich political, economic, and sociocultural heritage contained within the Barcelona process.

Regarding amendments for the Plenary, our Group has not submitted any, believing that doing so would, in some way, reinforce the balance achieved through commitments, and therefore we will oppose the majority of the amendments so as not to weaken the agreement reached in the Foreign Affairs Committee.
Mr. President, the referendum in Venezuela has resulted in a victory for the “yes” vote, gracefully acknowledged by the democratic opposition.

It is no less true that equality of opportunity has not existed in the campaign and that the incumbent administration has benefited from the overwhelming support of the entire state apparatus, while the opposition has suffered constant harassment and coercion.
Even under those conditions, the country has been practically divided into two halves, and it will be very difficult to build the future with only one of them.
The European Union must promote dialogue, inclusion, and consensus among Venezuelan political and social actors for the benefit of the country.
It is not through visceral attitudes, disparagement, or insults that we will help Venezuela find its democratic, pluralistic, and free path.

In that regard, we criticize the Venezuelan government's decision to expel a Spanish Member of the European Parliament and even more so the manner in which that expulsion was carried out, but we appeal to this Assembly to avoid

that our representatives make statements during their visits to third countries that violate local legislation, and even less so that they insult a head of state, however much this head of state may be criticized.
With these attitudes, we are jeopardizing future missions of the European Parliament to other countries.
Mr. President, I have just returned from Venezuela, where I was invited by its electoral authority as a member of an international electoral observation group for the referendum held on the 15th.

The European members of that group have submitted a report to the National Electoral Council, offering an overall positive assessment of the process regarding its organization, transparency, participation, free and secret exercise of the right to vote, and security in all its phases.

Regarding the statements made by Deputy Herrero to a Venezuelan television station, he indicated that they aimed to delegitimize the ongoing electoral process, leveled serious accusations against democratic institutions in that country, and bordered on interference in the internal politics of a sovereign nation.
Our Parliament should not foster any type of confrontation with the democratic institutions of Venezuela.
Conversely, it would be incumbent upon the honorable member of parliament to provide explanations to this Chamber regarding actions that impact us all.
The Budget Committee opines that the clear definition of each budgetary instrument is of the utmost importance.

Therefore, the most realistic option appears to be the creation of a new instrument for actions distinct from public development aid for countries falling within the scope of application of that Regulation.
From a budgetary perspective, the proposed funding from the Development Commission appears unsuitable, as that money does not exist.
Do not count those lines with a pluriannually assigned credit amount. There is a credit for 2009, but not beyond that.
In any event, given that the funding for this new cooperation instrument must be compatible with the financial framework for 2007-2013, it is advisable
remember the importance of the interim review of the financial framework, which should allow for an adjustment of the maximum limits of the various budget lines.
Madam President, at this late hour on Monday, the Committee likely has other matters of greater concern than this report.
Ultimately, what we are doing is nothing more than responding to a report from the Commission, a report on the implementation of Regulation 1206-2001.
Council of May twenty-eighth, two thousand and one, concerning cooperation between the judicial authorities of Member States in the field of obtaining evidence in civil or commercial matters.
We are in a decidedly non-community area, an intergovernmental sphere, in which the Council, through Regulation, has sought to stimulate cooperation among those judicial bodies.
But in doing so, I believe there is a certain lack of rigor on the part of the European Union.

That is to say, certain measures have been planned, for example, the issuance of practical guides, the use of electronic media, etc., but I acknowledge that action on the part of the Commission is quite difficult.

I don’t know what the Commission has achieved or intends to achieve, but it seems quite difficult to attain it given the enormous difficulty that this form of intergovernmental cooperation constitutes.

That is to say, we are asking judicial authorities to collaborate with one another—we are talking about 27 countries, judicial authorities handling 22 different languages, with very distinct legal systems—and we are attempting to achieve results.
The Commission has observed that the results are not satisfactory, that there is a significant delay in these cooperation mechanisms, and, of course, that we do not have the resources to do so.
Ideally, one would have material resources.
For example, what could the Commission do to equip judicial bodies, particularly those at a lower level, with technological resources such as a video conferencing system?
The video conference may be a utopia for many small courts across the European Union, but it appears to be the only way to achieve it.
I believe that the European Union should rely on existing institutions, specifically the European Judicial Network.
We should reinforce this institution so that judges themselves, through their systems of cooperation, could develop this type of communication.
On the other hand, any matter pertaining to judicial training is fundamental.
This is something the Commission also cannot do on its own.
but the Commission can indeed stimulate the development of this type of training courses in Community law and in the understanding of the various legal systems.
Then there is a significant difficulty, which is the language problem—that is, how can one communicate, let’s say, a Spanish judge with a Finnish judge with such different languages.
It cannot be expected that judges, in addition to having to manage their own law, which is already complex in itself, be obligated to have knowledge for these kinds of matters.
What practical steps can we take to facilitate the task of interpretation and translation for judges?
translation, that is, what could we do to help them do it?
In presenting this report, I express no rigor or harshness toward the Commission.
I believe the work is quite difficult.
What I would indeed like to know, taking advantage of the fact that we have a commissioner here who is interested in this topic, what does the commission think can be done to provide greater…
rigor to this 2001 regulation, somewhat imprecise, somewhat voluntaristic, and I'm not sure if, from a practical standpoint, it can have any consequence or if it can be used to achieve progress.
Mr. President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, I am very pleased to be able to conclude this legislature with the final approval of the last of the maritime packages.

However, I recall that when I arrived at the European Parliament in nineteen ninety-nine, we experienced a major maritime disaster, that of the Erika vessel, near the French coast, which gave its name to an initial block of legislative proposals aimed at mitigating and preventing accidents.

We believed we had already banished the danger, but shortly thereafter the coasts of Galicia were devastated by the sludge resulting from another accident even greater than the first, that of the ship.

Since then, within the Transport Committee, we have worked on successive legislative packages, attempting to overcome the excessive resistance we encountered from shipowners, oil companies, classification societies, and also from certain Member States who rejected our proposals for considering them too demanding.

Over these ten years, we have approved various Directives and Regulations, some of which we have had to revise because, as a result of cuts initiated by the Council, they proved ineffective in their initial drafting.

We approved the regulations for the introduction of double-hulled ships, the European Fund for large-scale oil catastrophes, safe havens, and now we review and approve the liability of passenger ship operators, the investigation of the

maritime accidents, the Community system for the monitoring and information on maritime traffic, control by the flag State of the port and, finally, the regulations and directives relating to ship inspection and classification organizations.
And all of this is good and desirable to come into effect and be applied by all Member States in the shortest possible time.
For this reason, I feel satisfied.
But the legislative term ends, I leave Parliament with the regret of not having managed to establish as mandatory the introduction of control systems that already exist.
They are patented to determine when and how many residues of centinelas and fuel tanks have been illegally discharged into the sea by a specific vessel.
that is, a type of black box otacometers that can be inspected by maritime authorities whenever a ship arrives in port.

I believe we owe the marine environment greater attention and stricter procedures to address the extensive pollution we generate, and if we fail to do so, it will affect our food chain and our lives, making us pay a high price.
I trust that it will not be necessary to wait another ten years to control marine discharges illegally more effectively and efficiently.
Mr. President, the review of the Eurovignette Directive is a matter of great importance that concerns and worries us all, especially peripheral countries, who feel they are victims of this proposal.
The European Commission has decided to address the internalisation of the external costs of road transport by imputing three new costs: air pollution, noise pollution, and congestion.

While the principles inspiring the proposal—those who use pay and those who pollute pay—are reasonable, the solution proposed is in no way justifiable, as it will be discriminatory toward a sector that has been suffering the disastrous effects of the economic crisis for months.
Demonizing road freight transport, even if it wasn't the objective, has proven to be the outcome.

This proposal, esteemed members, is untimely and, far from achieving the expected objectives of sustainable transportation, would be a death sentence for a large number of small and medium-sized European enterprises that employ thousands of people.

people in the European Union and who contribute daily to the distribution of goods, ensuring that products reach their final consumer—a consumer who will see their products become more expensive due to the application of these tariffs.
Honorable members, we need a competitive, sustainable, and environmentally friendly transportation system, without overlooking the road, because currently it is the only way to reach everywhere.
Modal shift remains a dream, far from being a reality.
Trans-European networks, maritime highways, and cross-border connections remain, in some instances, projects rather than realities.
Esteemed colleagues, when the bedrock of the global economy sinks, it is not possible to ask the orchestra to continue playing, let alone to play for joy.

Mr. President, the European Commission, on July 15, 2008, adopted a communication addressed to the Council and the Parliament, recommending the establishment of a strategic partnership between the European Union and Mexico.
For its part, the European External Action Service, on October thirteenth, recognized Mexico as a strategic partner, awaiting the Parliament's opinion on the matter.
Let us recall that already in the seventh meeting of the Joint Parliamentary Commission European Union Mexico, held at the end of October of last year, we stated that a.
This strategic association between Mexico and the European Union constitutes a necessary impetus to strengthen and develop the true potential of our bilateral relations.
We noted the opportune moment for relations between both parties and the positive assessment of the current Global Agreement.

We emphasize the need for our respective executives to strengthen collaboration in political, economic, and cooperative matters, particularly in light of the new challenges of all kinds arising from the financial and economic crisis that shakes our continents.

With the great nation that is Mexico, we share values and objectives such as the development of democratic forms of government, a commitment to gender equity, the consolidation of the rule of law, equitable and sustainable development, and respect for human rights.

We advocate for strengthening cooperation in the fight against organized crime, terrorism, and drug trafficking, based on the principles of shared responsibility and strict adherence to international law.
Consequently, we will support the proposal of recommendations regarding the Strategic Association European Union-Mexico, which will be presented to Parliament this morning.
Regarding the report on microcredit, I would like to congratulate all the speakers, as they have done a great job.
The Commission's initiative has undoubtedly improved.
I understand that the recommendations established here will allow us to serve as the foundation for developing a genuine framework within the European Union for the microcredit sector.
that has been successful in many developing countries, even in some European ones, both as an economic activity mechanism and as a tool for improving social inclusion and job creation.

but which had not been transferred to the sector or community context, and I believe that is an opportunity to do so, particularly starting from the economic and financial context in which we find ourselves.
Prioritarily, in that sense, reinforcing the initiatives being advanced here is essential, but further steps must be taken.
It is necessary to increase the funds available for this microcredit support structure.
It is necessary to facilitate access for individuals and businesses that lack access to loans, and in that regard, Madam President, I would like to highlight the example of the
the European guarantee for microcredit loans as an instrument that can facilitate that access and which has been included in the report.
And I conclude by thinking that, without a doubt, this will lay the groundwork for us to create a harmonious framework within the European context that promotes the microcredit sector.

Madam President, while we are discussing the budget, I believe we must prepare ourselves for the negotiation next year regarding the continuation of subsidies for coal, an essential indigenous energy source.
And I say this with due advance because, inappropriately, some high-ranking official, misleading public opinion, allowed themselves to express a contrary view, leaking it to an economic publication.
Nothing of the sort.
It will be necessary to continue supporting my country's coal after 2012, and I want that recorded in the minutes of the session.

Gentlemen, officials, please limit yourselves to complying with the current plan and, subsequently, starting in two thousand twelve, with the instrument that we will begin negotiating with the sector next year.
Mr. President, Commissioner, this question, as Mr. Boclan has explained, is very timely, given the diplomatic conference on the ship recycling convention that will be held in May.
Therefore, I would like to congratulate Mr. Brok, not only on the question, but also on the resolution he has prepared.

Within the People's Party, we support the fight against improper practices and methods employed in ship dismantling, and therefore, we support Mr. Brockland’s proposed resolution. However, there are certain points that concern us.

The first is section three, which he has also indicated, which states that ships in their entirety should be considered hazardous waste and, as a consequence, should fall within the scope of the Basel Convention.

We have presented an amendment on this section because there are different interpretations both within and outside the European Union, and we understand that the Basel Convention must be taken into account and should not contradict it, but the future international agreement on ship dismantling should define the details of its application.
The draft resolution also requests, in its fourteenth point, a financing mechanism based on mandatory contributions from the maritime transport sector.

It seems to us rather premature to discuss mandatory contributions at this time, when it has not yet been decided within the IMO what system will be adopted for this funding, and it seems to me that the European Commission also does not have a clear answer on this matter.
Finally, in point fifteen, the Commission is urged to clearly establish that the State with jurisdiction over waste is the responsible State.
We also do not believe it is the Commission's responsibility to decide this, which should also be determined in an international agreement.

The key is to ensure coherence regarding the future convention on ship recycling and the Basel Convention on the Control of Transboundary Movements of Hazardous Wastes and Their Disposal, and all of this taking into account not only the Basel Convention but all existing legislation.

Madam President, Madam Commissioner, colleagues, the first thing I would like to do is congratulate the rapporteur, with whom we share a great deal of agreement regarding this program, and congratulate ourselves all, because in times of economic crisis it is fundamental to maintain a program like this, with clear positive social effects.

Although we are facing a consultation procedure from the European Parliament, we must send a clear political signal that, in these moments of economic uncertainty from Brussels and Strasbourg, we are not exclusively concerned.
not only concerned with the recovery of the financial system, but fully aware that social policies, especially those supporting those who need it most, the poorest in the European Union, must grow.

This food distribution program must continue to be considered part of the common agricultural policy. Here, we concur with the Commission, not only because European agriculture has a distinct social character, but because it is an effective instrument, because it is needed now more than ever, and because it must continue to function.

From the Socialist Group, as is the case with the rapporteur, we oppose the confidentiality of this program between the European Union and its Member States, as this would entail discrimination among States based on their wealth, with the possibility that the program could not be implemented in the most needy countries.

It is difficult to understand why, when it is needed most, the Commission now wishes to economize on community funds in the most social aspect of the CAP, particularly considering that there are budgetary surpluses in the agricultural budget every year.
Full community funding is essential for us.
We need to ensure that this program reaches all countries and, above all, those most in need.
Forty-three million potential beneficiaries of this program demand greater effort and, in no case, that budgetary expenditure be economized.
Austerity, yes, but not with the most vulnerable.
And it is precisely to guarantee that it reaches the citizen of all Member States that the program must cover the entire journey of distributed food.

Therefore, from the Socialist Group, for which I am responsible for the report, we have presented an amendment so that all expenses derived from distribution, including those of transport, storage, and administrative costs, are covered by Community funds.
We also agree with the speaker that food should preferably be community-sourced and of quality.
It is a position consistent with that maintained by this Parliament in other similar programs that we recently discussed in this Chamber, such as the fruit distribution plan in schools.
That's all, and many thanks.
We hope that the Commission will consider the position of this Parliament when it votes and, above all, that the plan is implemented in the European Union as soon as possible.
The Arctic region is one of the most fragile regions of our planet.
The consequences of an unrestricted exploitation of its natural resources would be catastrophic, not only for the immediate environment and the indigenous population, but for the world as a whole.

The thawing of vast areas has brought these risks to the forefront, making a new, globally-reaching regulation necessary to protect the Arctic, similar to the one already in place for the Antarctic, even taking into account the differences highlighted in the debate.

An international treaty between all parties involved, including, without doubt, the European Union, is necessary to protect its unique environment, ensure the fully sustainable character of all types of human activities, and to multilaterally regulate navigation through the newly accessible waterways.
The Arctic Council, during its several years of existence, has been a model of cooperation for managing common problems.

In these moments of difficulty and uncertainty, we must elevate that spirit and that harmony to greater heights to prevent states in the region or other international actors from becoming embroiled in geostrategic conflicts, forgetting what should be the common objective: the preservation of a vast shared heritage.
Mr. President, unlike the two speakers who have just preceded me, I concur with the majority of those who have spoken.
This is a good Directive, an excellent Directive, aimed at protecting interpreters.
When discussing the need to seek a more intelligent model for doing business, what is actually being discussed is the elimination of intellectual property.
Business can only be conducted if there is an established right.
We already have an established right at the national level.
The Commission, under the direction of Mr. Macrivi, has adopted a courageous initiative, a positive initiative, and I believe the Parliament should approve the commitment that we have.
achieved within the scope of the Committee on Legal Affairs thanks to the work of the rapporteur, Mr. Crowley, and the various shadow rapporteurs, such as Ms. McGill and Mr. Tugong.
I believe it is a magnificent directive, a directive that will boost the creation of intellectual property.
Furthermore, that Directive includes several recommendations with respect to the continuation of the work.

I believe that this Chamber's approval of that report and I hope that the Council aligns with the lines of the Council, the Commission, and the Parliament will serve to ensure that in the next legislature…

The Commission should continue along this path, make proposals to the Parliament, and advance in the area of intellectual property protection, which is essential for the development of our European Union as a major institution based on a common culture.

Mr. President, the information you are giving me is correct, but the impression we, the European parliamentarians and, ultimately, European citizens, have is that there is a very dangerous gap in Community law.
At this moment, as fiscal demands are reinforced in each of the Member States, mobility is nearly impossible.
And when we ask the Commission the reason for the pragmatic approach, it is because the Commission never finds support in the Council.

We are in a sort of vicious circle whereby the Commission refers matters to the Council and the Council refers them back to the Commission. However, in the meantime, the reality is that citizens living in this Europe we wish to build do not have the possibility of living in different countries or establishing relationships as a consequence of the heavy fiscal burden that a lack of fiscal harmonization can entail.
fiscal. Can the Council do anything to help us break this vicious cycle?
Madam President, for once I am glad that the usual speaker is not present, that Mr. Tajani has come, because Mr. Tajani has the advantage of having been a Member of the European Parliament.
As a Member of the European Parliament, I know that you have experienced the frustration that we Members of the European Parliament feel regarding the implementation of Community Law.

Now, in Parliament we tend to take issue with the Commission. I believe we are asking the Commission an impossible task, because all of Community Law and all the application of Community Law is based on indirect application.

That is to say, the Commission has only a few officials at headquarters, where it receives some complaints and has a few avenues for action. But, at this moment, the trend is also to limit budgetary powers, meaning the Commission will not have the possibility to do so.
All Community law, all the application of Community law, is based on the actions of national authorities, national parliaments, national judges, national officials.
And here, in this aspect, I don’t believe we can demand too much of the Commission.
What we need to do is assist the Commission, and I believe that there are some points in Mrs. Frassoni’s report that may be useful in achieving this implementation.
I refer to those relating to the correlation of directives, the collaboration of national parliaments, and the actions of national courts.
Mr. President, two years ago, during a mission led by my colleague from this group, Marián, I had the opportunity to visit.
Sierra Leone and of being present in this Tribunal and of being aware of the immense work this Tribunal was undertaking, not only for Sierra Leone, but for all of humanity.
The Special Court for Sierra Leone, as has already been stated here, has set a precedent.

A precedent because, as the Resolution clearly indicates, it is the first international tribunal funded by voluntary contributions, the first tribunal created in the country where the alleged crimes occurred, and also the first tribunal, as has already been noted, in which a former prime minister has been tried.

For all these reasons, not only because it sets a precedent, but because it serves as a reference for other tribunals established in its wake, such as Rwanda, former Yugoslavia, Cambodia, or Lebanon, we consider it imperative that this Resolution be approved, on which we have been working jointly with the Tribunal for several months.
Two years ago, we approved a resolution to support its funding. Two years ago, the Tribunal was experiencing a difficult period in which it was running out of…
money and did not have sufficient support. We must also thank the European Commission here for coming out in support, let’s say, financially, of this Tribunal.

Now, above all, we request two things first: that convicted individuals serve their sentences. The functioning of the Tribunal itself, which ends next year, is at stake, as is the legacy this Tribunal will leave behind. Secondly, obviously, all of this must be accompanied by greater funding.
Ultimately, the Sierra Lona Special Tribunal is an example and a reference for all of us and for all the courts that have judged war crimes.

It is an example and a reference, and a lesson that the second poorest country on this planet is giving us, in which, upon entering the court, we saw a motto written that read: Without justice, there is no peace.
And precisely because of that, we have a moral obligation, not only as Europeans but as human beings, to ensure that the legacy of this Tribunal remains permanent in history.

Mr. President, with all due brevity, which I am sure my Lords and Ladies will appreciate at this hour, Mr. Vice-Chairman of the Committee, thank you once again, because you have demonstrated, as you did with the third package.

maritime, whose impetus, its political standing has been capable of driving an agreement near the Council and making possible that Parliament, Council, and Commission could agree at this instance and in these final days where the legislature concludes.
I believe we need to congratulate ourselves.
I undoubtedly appreciate the close collaboration that the speakers of opinion have had both in the JURI Committee and in the Environment Committee.

I acknowledge and reiterate the work and collaboration of the shadow rapporteurs, and ultimately, I believe that the agreement we adopt tomorrow in first reading on such an important regulation will undoubtedly complete the work of the

The third package on maritime affairs represents a success for this Parliament and for the European Union across its three institutions and, once again, justifies the co-decision procedure, which is useful and allows for constructive dialogue in favor of all citizens of the European Union.
I needed a minute before I wanted to respond to the police commissioner, who is aware of my friendship and affection for her, and, indeed, of my friendship and affection for Mr. Orbán.
But the police commissioner has not uttered a single word about the public defender’s recommendation.
That is to say, the ombudsman, who is familiar with all the arguments presented by the Commissioner, has made a precise recommendation that the Commission appears to disregard in its entirety.

I don't even want Mrs. Cuneva to reply to me because, evidently, she is not the one who has the data, but all the data she has given me is consistent with what we knew and with what the Public Defender also knows and isn't telling us whether or not

Despite all of that, and as the Ombudsman, who is aware of this, recommends changing the regulation, he does not tell us whether the Commission will assume what the Ombudsman requests and what the Parliament recommends based on the Ombudsman’s request.
Mr. President, I believe that the regulatory proposals submitted to us by the Commission are important and necessary, and on the other hand, it was also important and necessary that from the
We insisted on the principles on which the two rapporteurs of the European Parliament, Mr. Svieska and Mr. Depré, have also insisted, and that is the principle of community competition.
This concerns a matter of community competence wherein, for practical reasons, it is advisable to retain certain Member State competencies, but, as Mr. Barró stated, limited in scope and duration.
Community competence is unavailable, and neither the Council, nor the Commission, nor the Parliament has the power to relinquish those community competences.

Having established this, this is an exceptional procedure. I believe that the amendments we have discussed and presented, and which I believe will be approved by Parliament tomorrow, will allow for the approval of this package of measures in first reading.

But I also hope that, from the Commission's side, moving forward and building on this, we can make progress in the development of a genuine European private law, which is increasingly necessary, as has been highlighted, for example, by Mr. Sogor in his most recent intervention.
We are discussing the problems that directly affect people, and to the extent that we are able to resolve those problems for people, they will realize that the European Union has a function.

In conclusion, Mr. President, I would like to congratulate my colleagues, Mr. Debrey and Mr. Svieska, and to thank the Commission and the Council for their willingness to collaborate with us on this matter.

Madam President, Commissioner, I have signed this Resolution and requested to intervene in this matter because I was a witness to what was termed an expulsion, but which in reality was the abduction of our colleague, Luis Herrero.

Furthermore, I was able to observe that political persecution, abuse of power by the Chavista regime, intimidation by aggressors, threats, disregard for human dignity, and manipulative use of the justice system are commonplace in Venezuela, among other things.

The case of Manuel Chávez is the straw that broke the camel’s back and that has led to this Resolution, but there are thousands of cases as egregious as his cited in the Resolution and others that are not.

as in the case of Ligio Cedeño, who was born in the humble Caracas neighborhood of Petare, well known for its danger and, furthermore, because he voted for a mayor who was not from the Chavista regime.

Eligio studied thanks to the help of others and, specifically, with the support of Citibank, managed to found his own business, the Banco de Caracas, and, furthermore, later lived normally helping those most in need.
Today, however, he languishes in a Caracas prison illegally, after two years of having been detained without any coherent charge.
Their only crime is being part of the economic oligarchy.

Another case is that of Nilson Moreno, a student leader from the Universidad de los Andes, elected on multiple occasions to the University Council and president of the Federation of University Centers.
He won the 2003 elections against the current federation minister of Interior and Justice, and this is his crime.
Today he is charged with homicide, in the attempted form, violent lewd acts, and all of that despite having been exonerated from prior accusations.

Situations like yours are commonplace in this country, where the persecution of opponents with the intent of excluding them from political life and discouraging dissent have become everyday occurrences.

However, from here it is necessary to send a message of hope to Venezuelan democracy. Despite the difficulties, I am certain that democracy will prevail and that President Chávez will be defeated at the ballot box.

Madam President, Commissioner, it is indeed undeniable that progress has been made recently, but despite all that has been advanced, the southern part of the Union is burning and burning increasingly so.
Therefore, the resolution approved by this Parliament cannot be merely a resolution that serves to highlight the great concern caused to us by the misfortunes of others.
Wildfires occur for various reasons, but no one can deny that they are fueled by climate change.

And, irrespective of any responsibilities that may exist in certain states or in some autonomous communities, the truth is that this Parliament must clearly call on the Commission to act with expediency and to deploy all the resources at its disposal, which are considerable.
Neither the victims, nor the damages suffered, nor the reforestation needs understand bureaucracy, nor can they comprehend budgetary timelines.

It is necessary to prioritize and to act, and acting in this case involves modifying strategies, mobilizing resources, increasing them, and optimally coordinating preventive policies, demanding, when the

case, responsibilities to States that lack them, but assuming that this is not a problem for States in Southern Europe and that climate change does not only affect certain States—it affects all and is a common cause.
