Therefore, one of the principal tasks facing this Parliament in the near term must be to ensure that the European Union secures clear commitments at the upcoming Copenhagen Summit.

decisive measures to attenuate greenhouse gas emissions to the maximum extent possible, because, evidently, they are at the foundation of the fires, of their causes, and these, in turn, are the causes of further climate change.
Therefore, approving this Resolution is now the challenge for this Parliament, with all certainty.
But let that challenge set by the Commission be met, if, truly, Commissioner, you want to prevent the south of the Union—which does exist—from continuing to burn.
Mr. President, thank you very much for granting me the floor. I am addressing Mr. Barroso.

Mr. Barroso, I must tell you that I have followed you with great interest and profound respect for a long time, since you were a leader in a country that is very close to us and very dear, which is Portugal.
I must tell you, however, that you have me utterly astonished at present.

I am surprised for two reasons. Firstly, because you have demonstrated a disregard for the Group in which I am present, the Non-Inscrits Group, not conceiving of us even a minute of your time to come and tell us about your political proposals.
We represent many European citizens and you have demonstrated a disregard for all of our electors.
Secondly, due to the fragility of their political project, and the paucity of their political proposals in the document "Political Orientations for the Next Commission."
proposals that do not even manage to capture what you have defended throughout your own term as president of the Commission.
It has surprised me, in this regard, that matters such as energy, which throughout your term have been well addressed, now, when you offer us your…

Madam Commissioner, you concluded your remarks by telling us that there is a crisis in the dairy sector, but you began them by telling us that you had already taken all the necessary measures and that the situation was being resolved.
Look, correcting is the mark of the wise.
And that is a Spanish saying that could be very well applied to the case at hand today.

The dairy sector has been experiencing one of the most serious crises in its history for months, and despite this, due to a reluctance on your part, or that of the European Commission, or some governments – among which mine, the Spanish government, appears to be included – to reverse the decisions regarding the health checks of the CAP.
Those decisions were adopted without considering the fragility of this sector and in a market context very different from the one that emerged after that commitment was fulfilled.
It gives the impression that the Member States either did not want to or were unable to see the storm brewing at the time.
The reform soon became outdated due to the significant shift in the market, a shift that demonstrates the sector’s complete vulnerability to price volatility.

That large producers like France and Germany, countries that achieved, in absolute terms, the largest increase in their national production quotas within that agreement, are now the ones requesting a review of the decisions reached during the verification process, is quite thought-provoking.

In my understanding, the Member States erred and should have listened more attentively to the voices—among which I am counted—that requested postponing any definitive decision regarding the sector’s future until 2011.
It’s a shame they didn’t listen to us.
Listen. Do it now.
Mr. President, this Parliament is the Palace of the Chimera, it is the Palace of Dreams.
The Irish people, with their strong vote, give us encouragement and strength to continue flourishing and to build a strong Europe and, above all, a federal Europe.
Only thus, only thus would we deserve the title of legitimate heirs of the parents of Europe, for whose labor we all are here.

Mr. President, having overcome the concern generated by the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon, it is, in my opinion, time to consider the treatment that should be given in the future to the nationalist attitudes that so impede European construction.
My understanding is that these impediments cannot come without a cost.
With a clear head, it is time to consider the possible measures to be adopted in the coming days and years.
This modest deputy desires a future President of the Council who is a man, or better, a woman, convinced of European federalism, and who manages the…
euro, which is located within the Schengen Area and which is identified and committed to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the Union. Thank you very much, Mr. President.
That is to say, on behalf of the Commission, I have nothing further to add, but I had already prepared the statement on behalf of the Socialist Group.

The breakdown of the constitutional order in Honduras breaks two decades without coups in Latin America and creates a perverse precedent for other countries, especially the weaker ones, as is now the case with Paraguay.
The European Parliament cannot and must not remain deaf and mute in the face of such a violation of the rule of law.

Both the Council and the Commission have unequivocally condemned the coup, supporting the mediation efforts of President Arias, in line with the position unanimously adopted by the OAS with the backing of the United Nations.

The self-proclaimed de facto president, Michelete, has failed to uphold the agreements reached recently, mocking the international community and preventing, among other measures, the return of the incumbent president, Mr. Celaya, to office.

Under the current circumstances, the election of a new president in the polls scheduled for November twenty-ninth suffers from a fundamental lack of legitimacy, and its results cannot and should not be recognized by the international community.

The European Parliament would commit a serious error if it sent a delegation to observe the elections, because this would be interpreted as an endorsement of the coup d'état. The OAS has already ruled out sending an observation mission to these elections.
This Parliament is recognized for being a guarantor of freedom, democracy, the rule of law, and respect for human rights.
As Baclar Havel stated this morning, there cannot be two weights or two measures.

We are all democrats here and, consequently, advocates of freedom. And therefore, let us speak of Cuba, of China, of North Korea, or now of Honduras—our discourse must be firm in the face of those who suppress freedom.
Let us not be blinded by our ideological preference.
There are no right-wing or left-wing coup plotters or dictators, only liberticides and repressors.

Many of us fear that things in Honduras will not change, and with that, a very dangerous precedent will have been created, and the doctrine of the good, temporary, and not overly cruel coup will have triumphed.

Mr. President, I would like to congratulate the members of the ENVI Committee and its President, Mr. Leinen, for the work they have done to enable us to have a resolution like the one we have and which we must approve decisively.
We cannot settle for simply stating that sector agreements are sufficient, because speaking of a patchwork agreement already admits a portion of the failure.
We have decided to approve this Resolution, which has three noble aspirations.
A more evident one is avoiding climate change with concrete proposals for emissions reduction and with a commitment to financing, and aspiring to a binding agreement, I say not of fragments.

and two latent aspirations: one, to begin earlier rather than later working towards a common energy policy, as we once endowed ourselves with a common agricultural policy because it was needed, and the other, of course, which is also included, to regain citizens’ trust in politics and in politicians – something we have in abundance in Europe.
In that sense, the success of the Summit will be the success of the three aspirations.
Therefore, I encourage the acting president of the Council to continue with his optimism, to press and negotiate all that he can to bring others along to this success.

I do not know if the leaders of this multipolar world wish to be discredited by history for failing to achieve a binding agreement, but I, as a parliamentarian, and I believe all representatives of the peoples, cannot be discredited by history for having failed in Copenhagen to secure the binding commitment we have to humanity to avoid climate change.

Today, there is no doubt of the European Union’s commitment to the fight against terrorism, and thanks to the Stockholm Treaty, the Stockholm Programme, we will continue to advance in this space of freedom, justice, and security that is so necessary.

However, in my view, this struggle has been predicated on mutual trust among the Member States, but the time has come, and with the possibilities afforded to us by the Treaty of Lisbon, to harmonize national legislation in the direction of the non-prescription of terrorist offenses, which should be considered crimes against humanity.

The day this happens, no one in this Parliament or any other will defend terrorists, as has occurred, occurs, and could continue to occur, with the consequent damage to the victims of terrorism, who see how those who murdered their loved ones are treated as heroes, while they suffer in silence.
I therefore request that this Parliament promote or adopt the European Charter of the Rights of Victims of Terrorism, based on the defense of memory.
Mr. President, I would first like to congratulate Mrs. McGuinness on this initiative, which highlights the important role of the CAP in addressing food supply needs on an international scale.

Now that the European Commission appears to want to reduce the weight of the CAP within the community budget, it must be stated very clearly that the CAP is no longer a priority, but food sufficiency certainly should be, and in past decades it has been seen that without the CAP food sufficiency is very difficult, if not impossible, to achieve.
Therefore, agriculture cannot be compared to other sectors of the economy capable of thriving in a free market, because the food market is not a free market.

The farmer needs the support of the European Union to be able to develop his business, and the Union, in turn, needs the farmer to maintain an agricultural model capable of providing sufficient and high-quality food to an increasingly demanding consumer.
Therefore, I believe that a shift in direction within the CAP would need to occur, but not its disappearance.

To achieve this, it would be necessary to guarantee direct subsidies to farmers, in addition to restoring a market management policy that provides greater stability in prices, which would have a positive impact not only on farmers, but also on consumers and third-country nations.

It would be necessary to establish a framework of good practices to foster balanced relationships among the various actors in the food chain, avoiding abusive practices and promoting a more equitable distribution of commercial margins.
Furthermore, a consumer information policy is needed for European consumers that emphasizes the efforts undertaken by Community producers to comply with European Union environmental regulations.
environment, food security, and animal welfare, because community producers have to compete with productions from third countries, where, for those imports, much lower standards are applied.

And those producers from third countries prefer to export to the European Union rather than supply their own national markets for a matter of genuine profitability, with the endorsement of WTO negotiations.
According to a United Nations report, in 2009 approximately two thousand seven hundred individuals were victims of human trafficking in the European Union.

With these figures in hand, it is necessary that the action of the European Union be based primarily on the protection of victims, with particular attention to the situation of women and children, who are the most vulnerable.
We cannot continue to stand idly by as witnesses to this theater, this spectacle of sexual exploitation unfolding before our eyes.

Therefore, I fully support this Parliament’s request regarding the provision of assistance to victims, which should be unconditional, more robust, and accompanied by more severe penalties, as Mr. Barrott just stated.
Having said this, I would like to request the President and the Council to utilize all European legislation at their disposal, both existing and future, to protect victims of human trafficking.

I believe that the proposal for a European protection order for victims, which I personally requested from the Spanish Presidency during the debates on the Stockholm Programme and which has finally come to fruition, will be an effective instrument in the fight against these crimes.

I expect a firm commitment, as we have already seen, from the Spanish Presidency to ensure that this order offers victims special protection measures that are effective throughout the territory of the European Union.

I hope that those of us with the responsibility to act on the most serious problems facing our society will provide a real and concrete response to this grave issue of human trafficking and that we do not remain solely with good intentions.
We truly owe it to all the victims.
Mr. Zapatero, for a Spaniard such as myself, it is an honor to greet your presence here in your capacity as President of the European Union.
There are many expectations and challenges associated with this period, and, of course, we cannot fail to meet the expectations created.
that citizenship sees that our renewed institutions are an instrument capable of contributing solutions to real problems.
But we have presented it, because your Lordship knows it is shared by us.
that for the Partido Popular of Spain this is a matter of state and that we will be supporting their Lordship in everything we see as being common interests of Europe and that is important for Spain.
It is an ambitious program, and it is a program that, hopefully, will be filled with content.
I would like it so that in that album of the Spanish Presidency, people can see – since it will surely be colorful and varied – in each event a milestone regarding real problems that affect them.
The crisis is hitting economies, and unemployment seems like a fifth horseman of the apocalypse.
You have had the honesty to acknowledge that twenty percent of unemployment exists in Spain, but that does not incapacitate you.
What I believe is that it obligates all of us to produce a solution to a problem that we genuinely need to solve together.
That was a real problem.
Time does not permit me to say many things, Mr. President.

But I do want to tell you that Spain faces many challenges ahead, challenges which, I believe, I am certain of, regarding Spain’s capabilities as a nation, and I want to believe and I am certain that you will rise to the occasion for our country.

We cannot fail to meet these expectations at this moment for Europe. On the other hand, the globalized world – a point which has been recognized with intelligence – results in the emergence of new power centers, and it is necessary that the European Union play a more active and coherent role in the defense of its values and interests.
Otherwise, we run the risk of becoming irrelevant.
Finally, Mr. President, Spaniards do not accept that anyone should question our ability to make proposals.
We possess that legitimacy.
We must also possess the humility to accept those counsels from Don Quixote that Sancho offered him when he recommended humility in the envisioning of the Barataria island government.
I am pleased to say that José Luis Zapatero has continued to surprise European women with measures of great innovation and progress.
Indeed, the formation of a truly egalitarian government and the courageous manner in which it has brought gender equality and respect for others to the national and European agenda.
Mr. President, I warmly congratulate you on your ambitious action program, certainly against gender-based violence, which is a social scourge.
The creation of a European Observatory on Gender-Based Violence is a pioneering proposal that European women support and applaud.
Mr. President, on behalf of the Portuguese socialists, I wish you good luck.
You can count on our solidarity.
solidarity between women and the shoemaker.
Mr. President, in a matter as serious as terrorism, we should not wait for events to unfold before taking action.
We should anticipate this, but we do not.
And, regrettably, we are advancing through acts of aggression such as the failed Detroit bombing, which compels us today to make decisions that guarantee the safety of air transport.
Deciding on the use of body scanners in airports is a responsibility that we cannot evade, ladies and gentlemen.
We cannot continue waiting because terrorists do not wait.
Therefore, the Commission must as soon as possible guarantee us that the dignity and privacy of individuals will be preserved and that there will be no adverse effects on health.
Once this is guaranteed, we must adopt decisions for the entire European Union.

And those who fear that fundamental rights will be violated, I will say to them that there is no right higher than the right to live. And those of us who love freedom above all else, we need to live securely in order to feel truly free.
Mr. President, I believe this crisis is an opportunity to advance with firmness and conviction in the creation of a strong Europe.

In that strong Europe, it is likely that the expression "improve coordination" should be dispensed with, as it makes everything dependent on the subjects to be coordinated and, strictly speaking, refers to paralysis and indefiniteness.
We know that the finances and public debts of European countries will suffer as long as progress is not made towards European financial integration and eurobonds are not issued.

In any case, European institutions can already undertake concrete actions. I will not reiterate the rhetoric of coordination. And there, for one thing, is the European Central Bank to harmonize financial supervision.
Good evening. I wanted to say that I have not come to this Parliament to applaud the recently enacted law in Spain on abortion.

What concerns me is human life, and I am particularly concerned about defending women whose lives are endangered by gender-based violence and offering them a space in which they can live free and safely.

This Parliament’s Resolution of 2 February 2006 recommends that the Member States adopt a zero-tolerance attitude towards all forms of violence against women and that they adopt the necessary measures to ensure better protection for victims.

The Stockholm Programme, approved in this Chamber, established a space of freedom, justice, and security for all European citizens, and it considered the fight against gender-based violence a priority.

It reflected my request to the Spanish Presidency that, during its term, it promote a European protection order for victims of gender-based violence, to ensure that victims of these crimes enjoy the same level of protection in all Member States.

In a Europe without borders, the fight against gender-based violence should also be without borders, and Member States should strive to harmonize their legislation so that the idea that the fight against abuse of women transcends…

legislative obstacles and ultimately, we could offer—at least within the European Union—we could protect the lives of women and their children. I therefore ask the Commission and the Council to do everything possible.

necessary and everything in its power to ensure the success of this European Protection Order for Victims, which is a very effective instrument for combating the impunity of those who do not respect the dignity of women or their right to live free and safe.

It has been a long time since Fidel Castro and his oligarchy ended the ideals of the Cuban Revolution, which resonated so deeply and inspired such hope for peoples around the world, for the best and brightest of international youth.
What characterizes, however, the Castro brothers’ dictatorship at this moment is the impiety toward political and conscientious prisoners, the impiety against their own people.
It reminds me of Franco, with the mistreatment of political prisoners he also considered common, his same obsessive disdain for exiles.
Castro ends up as Franco and all enemies of freedom when they become entrenched in power.
But we must save lives and be supportive of those who fight and suffer.
It is our obligation as Europeans committed to democracy, freedom, and human rights.
Madam President, President of the Council, Commissioner, let us never again allow our silence to become complicity with those who curtail freedoms.

Never again shall we permit a person who fought for their rights and the rights of all to die in a Cuban prison or any other place without our voice rising, strong and steadfast, demanding their salvation.

Mr. Orlando Zapata Tamayo, a forty-two-year-old man of color, a bricklayer who simply requested improvements to prison conditions, died after eighty-six days of a hunger strike and seven years in prison for demanding respect for human rights.
and during those seven years he was mistreated, humiliated, and abused by his jailers, a fact that must be remembered amidst a dense silence from the international community.
Other prisoners and human rights activists in Cuba are now on hunger strike, including psychologist and journalist Guillermo Fariñas.

Honorable members, the resolution we present today, which we debate today, and which we will vote on tomorrow, and which I represent on behalf of the Social Democratic Group, demands the release of all prisoners of conscience in Cuba.
It speaks once more in favor of a democratic transition and the strict respect for fundamental human rights.
Let us not, for the moment, delve into a topic that divides us regarding whether or not to maintain the common position.
Let us now focus on the topic of saving lives and human rights.
and let us open a period of serene reflection in which we seek common ground on the issues of Cuba’s future policy.
But this text also possesses a significant added value.
The fact that it is being presented by six political groups expresses a new era of broad consensus in this Chamber on the issue of human rights.

Let it never again be asserted that European democratic right-wing parties conform to the so-called dictates of Yankee imperialism, but also let it never again be said that social democrats are acquiescent or complicit with communist dictatorship.
Simply because both assertions are false, and the victims of the liberticides, wherever they may be, must know that they will find us united in the unconditional defense of their cause.
Mr. President, lastly, I would like to thank Mr. Salafranca, who negotiated this text on behalf of the European People's Party, Ms. Weber from the Alliance of Democrats and Liberals Group, and Mr.

Thank you, Mrs. Romeva, on behalf of the Green Group, to Mr. Kasutnik, from the European Conservatives and Reformists, and to other colleagues who have participated in this difficult, complicated, but I hope tomorrow successful effort.

Finally, I also want to thank the President of the Spanish Government and the President of the European Union in office, Mr. José Luis Rodríguez Zapatero, for his encouragement and support in moving forward this Resolution that we are debating today.
History will absolve me was the famous plea of a young lawyer who stirred his people.
History, in effect, acquits him of his rebellion against tyranny and subsequently against the North American blockade.
But with the same emphatic condemnation, this Parliament, which represents the largest space of freedom and democracy in the world, condemns the dictatorship that...
The people of Cuba suffer from the violation of human rights on the island, the irreverence toward political prisoners, the disdain toward their exiled nationals.
The judgment of history is clear.
With this Resolution, deputies of all ideologies, we stand alongside the Cubans who are fighting.
One must avoid, by all possible means, the brutal repression they suffer, even surpassing the paralyzing effect of the Common Position.
tribute to the poet Raúl Rivero in the final verse of his Habana. Do not impose taxes on affection, emptiness, suffocation, bitterness.
The ruins of the homeland are secure.
Calm down, colleagues.
We're leaving now.
This week, International Women's Day was celebrated.
In this Parliament, we saw many posters in all the languages of the European Union stating that yes, violence against women can be eradicated.
Today we are discussing violence in Mexico, and it seems reasonable to acknowledge that Mexican women, indigenous and non-indigenous, are the least protected victims by local and federal authorities.
Mexican women are victims of all forms of violence, from domestic violence to sexual violence and torture perpetrated by members of the military or the police, and even homicide.
Unfortunately, thus far the responses from Mexican authorities have been ineffective, and for that reason, it is correctly spoken of near absolute impunity.
Our resolution calls on the Mexican government to combat feminicides – a harsh but accurate term when we see that nearly all murders committed against women remain unpunished.
An example in the State of Mexico, over the past four years, was that only eleven of the criminals who murdered nearly seven hundred women were convicted.
At the same time, it appears that women are the preferred victims of the judicial system.
There is no other way to explain how it was possible for two Indigenous women, Alberta Alcántara and Teresa González, to be sentenced to 21 years in prison and up to
Now, more than three years have passed in prison for looting Erasolitas during an incident in a market, six men from the Federal Investigation Agency.

investigation. Let us hope that the judge, who will decide in a week on the appeal in this case, realizes the absurdity and injustice of the situation. But violence against women begins in the family.

I hope that Mexican legislators will soon improve the General Law on Women's Access to a Life Free of Violence so that types of violence are defined and mechanisms are established to make the regulations operational.
Similarly, it would be natural to establish that domestic violence and marital rape are criminal offenses.
Furthermore, for Mexican society to change and reject violence against women, it is important that in schools this topic becomes a primary concern of youth education.
Madam President, the truth is that the first thing I would like to do tonight is to thank Mr. Escoté for his excellent willingness to negotiate this report.
It has been a genuine pleasure working with him and with the other spokespersons for the parliamentary groups.

We are proud of the position that will be demonstrated tomorrow in the vote in this European Parliament, and we are proud of a position like this, which defends quality, which champions the development and enhancement of rural areas, not only as…

not mere testimonies of a traditional European culture, but as genuine generators of wealth and employment—employment that we so sorely need now, at this time of economic crisis and the dramatic employment situation in some Member States.
We also appreciate the defense upheld by this European Parliament and the position already clearly articulated by the Committee on Agriculture: to prioritize quality to the greatest extent possible.
And at that highest level, we unequivocally advocate for maintaining this differentiation between protected designations of origin and protected geographical indications.
Certainly, we reject the notion of lowering standards and want attention to be paid to, and value placed upon, community production.
I applaud Commissioner Cholo's words.
It was, of course, pleasant to hear him speak of the commitment to the future of European agriculture.
We certainly hope you will heed that voice of this Parliament, which will be made clear tomorrow in that vote.

Finally, I want to say that we hope it never happens again that the European Commission preempts this Parliament by prohibiting things like, for example, marketing standards for fruits and vegetables, which have done so much damage to European free competition.
We want market imbalances to be corrected and we also want to invest in quality, variety, food safety, and an adequate level of production.
We also want community productions and the quality of those community agro-food products to be defended within the World Trade Organization.
And for that, we also count on the work of Commissioner Cholos, because neither our producers nor our European consumers can remain defenseless.
Mr. President, the Commissioner has spoken of the absurdity and obsolescence of the procedures.
Let us, then, be consistent.
We have lost too many opportunities, too many agreements to introduce community competition over European airspace.
But if we were unable to intervene as we should have in the sky, we could certainly do so in the skin of the earth.
for example, monitoring passenger rights and also mediating or requesting a truce in the various collective conflicts of land transportation.
No bare-bones services, maximum services to all parties.
Thank you very much, Madam President. When, from distinct and distant positions, such as those of Mauro, Gollnisch, or Coleman, one arrives at the conclusion that…
The procedure, electoral systems, and the election of Members of the European Parliament present challenges. That means, Madam President, that we need a uniform electoral procedure.

that was a mandate already established in the Treaties of Rome. Therefore, the coordinators—and I want to take this opportunity to express my gratitude to everyone, but especially to Messrs. Jauregui and Duff—have agreed to an amendment.

2. Tomorrow, a vote will be held, and I hope this Chamber will support it, precisely so that we can resolve this matter, this issue of a uniform electoral procedure for the European Parliament elections, in the near future.
It seems to me that with that, we would eliminate this type of query.
In his address, Mr. Traskowski spoke of the necessary representativeness of this Chamber, and this is a factor that most speakers, including the Vice President Shevkovich, have highlighted.
I agree, and we state in article one of the report that the eighteen should enter as a bloc, because otherwise, we would lose representativeness.

And so that they can act as a bloc, to fulfill that act of political justice that is the Lisbon Agreement, we must, Honorable Senator, be pragmatic, because a transitional and exceptional situation also requires transitional and exceptional measures or solutions.

And that is why I do not conceal it. I do not like the possibility of deputies entering this Chamber who have not emerged from the elections of two thousand nine. I say this with all clarity in paragraph two. But if I have to choose between that and not…

bring in the eighteen, or seek a pragmatic solution, one that brings in the eighteen and thus fulfills the Lisbon Agreement. Therefore, I ask this Chamber, and this is the basis of my report, to opt for that transitional, pragmatic, but above all, Madam President, just solution.
Thank you very much to everyone for the collaboration and the interesting contributions you have made to this work.

As I was unable to do on March 11th, International Day of Victims of Terrorism, I would today, from this Parliament, wish to pay them a well-deserved tribute that recognizes the immense sacrifice of those who have paid the highest price in the name of freedom.

It is urgent to begin working on a Directive that protects the rights of victims of terrorism, who are always the forgotten ones and bear the humiliation of being unjustly equated with their tormentors.
It is now time for these European institutions to recognize the dignity of victims of terrorism and to assist them in their right to protection and justice, which should soon be translated into law.

that will honor all those who make it possible and that the first article be that support for victims of terrorism is recognized as having the right to justice and that no government ever pays a political price.

I issue a call to all those who can defend victims, so that they never forget that true peace is the peace born of justice, and that is the only peace we must defend, from Europe and from any place in the world, those of us who believe in justice.

It has been necessary, Mr. President, to find ourselves facing the abyss and economic collapse for heads of state and government to understand that the path is not one of more nationalism, but of more Europe.
At this juncture, measures such as the decline of the veto power in the European Council or the genesis of a European public asset are in circulation.
Finally, albeit belatedly, we have learned that we are all navigating the same vessel and that addressing individual situations is futile, and moreover, doing so in an ad hoc manner.

But I wonder if this attitude is a parenthesis or, conversely, the beginning of a genuine European economic government, because what is lacking, dear colleagues, is governance and what is missing is authentic government if we want to remain faithful to the testament of the founding fathers.
Therefore, from this Parliament, we must promote all those reforms that aim to strengthen Europe and make budgetary and fiscal discipline a reality, forgetting, incidentally, nostalgic sovereignties.
Colleagues, strengthening the European Commission and strengthening this Parliament is the only sound recipe for building a Europe that, otherwise, would vanish like a fleeting shadow.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, from the INTA Committee, thank you to Ms. Sarnez for the collaboration we have had.
Now more than ever, unity around the Mediterranean is necessary, as is the strengthening of major projects and institutional development.
Now more than ever, it is necessary to find solutions to overcoming the crisis, to research, to climate change, to water, to new energy models, and to sustainable development.

To that end, it is necessary to promote and finalize commercial and economic relationships in the region, with measures in the short and long term, including a free trade zone, elimination of tariff barriers, and opening of the North-South and South-South markets.
The Barcelona Summit, the Spanish Presidency, will offer the possibility of a new commitment, a new situation, a new shared endeavor, of democratization, of economic and social solutions.
The Barcelona Summit could position us to lead the Mediterranean.
Madam President, within the trans-European transport corridors is the railway corridor known as the Mediterranean Corridor.
It is a vital communication that will connect North Africa with Europe.
For Spain, it is vital because this axis is a priority, given that it would connect Algeciras with Europe.
Without excluding other priority corridors, it would pass through Almería, Murcia, the Valencian Community, and Catalonia.
And why? That is what Commissioner Reding said, she said increased economic activity and a significant concentration of ground transportation.
This is one of the two conditions.
The possibility arose of communicating with various ports in the Mediterranean area.
Economic momentum must be gained, competitiveness fostered—as the commissioner also stated—because in this region, over fifty percent of Spanish exports originate.
Therefore, if we expand the scope of a strategic railway axis through the Mediterranean, we will increase competitiveness for Spain and greater competitiveness for Europe.
Madam President, I wanted to take this minute to congratulate the rotating Spanish presidency on the efforts it has made this semester to overcome the…
a common position with respect to Cuba and create a new type of relationship between the European Union and Cuba that includes, naturally, as a priority matter, the defense of human rights.
That policy has not been crowned with success, primarily due to the intransigence of the Cuban dictatorship, which began this Presidency in January of.

This year, with the expulsion of the Member of Parliament addressing you, when attempting to visit—with all necessary visas and in full compliance with the law—the island to address human rights concerns there.
But that policy, that new policy undertaken by the Spanish Government, will yield results sooner rather than later.

Mr. President, Commissioner, colleagues, this is a regulation of utmost importance to consumers and the agri-food industry, because it is not at all easy to achieve balanced labelling that contains everything essential, but is not so exhaustive as to complicate the information.
This is an excellent report, and the presenter deserves congratulations for it.
I concur with her on the major issues relating to nutritional information and the controversial topic of profiles, especially considering that the Commission did not fulfill its
commitment to establish said profiles, as well as their terms of use, before January nineteenth, two thousand nine, as prescribed by Regulation 1924/2006.

There is a matter that concerns me, and it is the possibility of the coexistence of national rules for labeling, because it goes against the objective of the legislation, which is harmonization and avoiding all possible obstacles to the functioning of a genuine single market.
Regarding the indication of country of origin, current legislation stipulates that this information must be provided when, in the absence of an indication, it could mislead the consumer.
Furthermore, voluntary labeling is always expected to be in place.
Going further can complicate matters, it can entail economic costs and administrative complexity for businesses without providing any significant, clear benefit to the consumer.
And regarding the use of different languages, I must say that the Commission’s proposal aligns with the existing Directive, which has functioned well and has not presented problems.
And reopening this debate could prove dangerous and unnecessary, and create problems for the circulation of goods.
Mr. President, the best demonstration of our good will is the thousand amendments we are seeing from the Committee to the Floor.

However, in addition to goodwill, I believe we must be practical when it comes to food labeling, if we do not want to achieve the opposite effect of what we pursue, that is, confusing the consumer instead of helping them to become informed.
It is not a matter of illustrating, but of preventing, of informing them about what they can eat and to what extent.
measure. It is necessary to label regarding fats, regarding sugars, regarding trans fats.
Indeed.
Indeed, regarding what affects cholesterol, concerning all those substances that affect what we have discussed—obesity and people's health.

Yes, but other foods with additional information, such as place of origin when it does not lead to confusion, or, for example, in meat, specifying the place of birth, the place of transit, the grazing location, and the slaughter site of the cattle can be very illustrative, but they will ultimately cause confusion.

It is up to us to ensure we are practical and that this regulation is established as the one that will harmonize and inform consumers, or, conversely, as the one that will confuse them even more and impose matters that, far from achieving better health outcomes, will result in greater confusion.

Therefore, I suggest, for example, that some of us opt for GDA, the daily intake amount, rather than the traffic light system, because it is very clear that if you consume this amount or double it, you will gain weight; therefore, consume only one.
The amount of daily intake versus other types of codes is what some propose to avoid further confusing the consumer.
Madam President, thank you very much, Mr. Martín Fraguero, for being here on behalf of the Spanish Presidency in a report such as this, Madam Commissioner.
Mr. Milana, congratulations on your ability to reach a common agreement and to bring all interests to the table, presenting an initiative report—one of the first initiative reports.
The deployment of aquaculture is important.

It is necessary due to the increase in fish consumption and the stagnation of fishing extraction capacity. But I want to emphasize at this time the economic importance of this activity, which generates economic wealth and creates employment.
It is important to have health guarantees, it is important to have sustainability, and it is important to have protection of the marine environment.
It is necessary to strengthen the image of aquaculture, as well as the scientific and research sector.
Aquaculture is an opportunity, as Mr. Martín Fraguero has said, within the PCP, as the Commissioner was saying.

It is necessary to provide it with a coherent framework for coordination, to give it the possibility of regularization, because aquaculture can represent sufficiency, sustainability, and economic resources, and I believe it is important for Europe.

Mr. President, in my opinion, this excellent report outlines the guiding principles that should inspire the new Transport White Paper, which will shape European transport policy for the next ten years.

This report features several key milestones, notably the necessity of a financial fund as an indispensable instrument, the challenge of the increasing demand for freight transport, and the pursuit of multimodal solutions that

contribute to the safety of users and goods the imperative need for sufficient and secure rest areas in road transport the diagnosis, in my opinion, accurate, that a mere competition between the various

modes, but rather to complement each other by seeking efficiency criteria. The speaker's assertion, which I consider courageous and just, that rail or maritime transport is not always more environmentally respectful than road transport.
Ultimately, the concept of an efficient community is a future-oriented concept and, in my view, should undoubtedly be supported with all due rigor.
It is yours, Mr. President, a flawed premise.
Did you truly believe you would preside over Europe and influence the mechanisms that drive the complex European machinery?
He came to believe it even, because he allowed people close to you to proclaim that the world was to live through a stellar moment under his Presidency.
None of this has come to fruition.
Let's move on to some clarifications.

Over these past six months of the Spanish Presidency, I would like to distinguish, on the one hand, between the political direction of it and, on the other, the work of the officials who have been working behind the scenes.
It is the first one that has failed, and this is due to the absence of adequate impetus from the Presidency of the Government, which has rather swung like a pendulum.
However, I want to highlight the effort of the officials, their valuable willingness to serve Europe and Spain.
And it is the case, Mr. President, that Spain has magnificent professional civil servants, and if there is something to lament, it is that they are marginalized too much in daily reality.
Having said this, it is necessary to acknowledge that some commendable initiatives have been adopted in these six months.
Among them, I am pleased to cite the organ donation and transplantation plan and the treatment afforded to patients' rights in cross-border healthcare.
More remains unresolved regarding the agreements on the new 2020 Strategy and, above all, those relating to the European External Action Service, both still too fragile.
It has been regrettable what has occurred with the European Protection Order for Victims of Gender-Based Violence, and the same somber outcome has been offered by the
Basic Community Patent, vital for the life of thousands of companies, and partly blocked by the linguistic problems fostered by Spanish legislation.

But it is all major political actions that have ended in spectacular failure, from the Mediterranean Summit to the European Union summit with the United States—the latter, regarding which its own government was responsible for creating excessive expectations.
However, we must concede that the inability to advance its policy regarding Cuba has been highly positive for Cubans.
Finally, the advances made on the path towards better European economic governance cannot, in any way, be attributed to its Presidency, clamorously absent in the most relevant matters.
Farewell, then, to the Spanish Presidency.

A positive conclusion I do want to draw from this experience is that my fantasy of a confirmed Europeanist is excited at the thought that it could signify the end of rotating presidencies, as they have been conceived up until now.

Would this be good news? For as long as Europe does not strengthen its common institutions, firmly uniting its fragments, it will continue to run the risk of being submerged in the empty spaces of irrelevance.
Mr. President, believe me, Mr. Zapatero, that I would have liked to deliver a different speech today.
He proposed, Your Honor, a semester brimming with ambition and set such a high standard for his expectations that, when compared with what was actually achieved, disappointment is inevitable.
The truth is that his Lordship has not been able to overcome a complex situation requiring leadership and credibility.
Your Lordship has recalled that the European Union is a club with rules, and I concur.
But it was you, Your Honor, to whom it corresponded to demand compliance with those rules.
The reality is that it was the Government of Spain that imperatively demanded fulfillment of its obligations.
In this depiction, positive achievements have been obscured.
Your Honor has had time to recount them; I have not.
Democracy, Honorable Members, is a regime of public opinion.

It appears to be the case. Obama’s disdain, the cancellation of the Mediterranean Summit, and the announced European Union and United States partnership constitute failures of considerable significance.

The pursuit of closing makeshift agreements at any price has not favored the image of Spanish management, which has been described as a botch job in the way it seeks to achieve even respectable objectives.
Spain is a great nation and will continue to be so, despite poor management of this time.
Our diplomats and officials have held their own, and as a result, the prestige of Spain will endure.
The truth is that the value judgment made about this Presidency will weigh more heavily on Spain’s situation than on what has or has not been done here.
It would be difficult for him to lead such a challenging company, given that he has placed his country in a period of uncertainty and disquiet.
At best, this Presidency has proven sadly irrelevant.
Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in the coming months we will fully enter into the debate on the new CAP.

It is important to reach a good agreement, so I hope that the Belgian Presidency achieves what the Spanish Presidency has not, that is, to channel the discussions so that Member States commit to maintaining a policy in the future.

a truly robust common agricultural policy, with a sufficient budget to address the needs of all twenty-seven Member States, both old and new, and that we do not repeat what happened in 2005, when funds were lacking and modulation had to be invented.

In the upcoming reform of the CAP, we are betting on the viability of a sector that not only provides intangible goods and services such as environmental stewardship, but should also ensure the provision of food to European citizens.

We have already witnessed painful situations of scarcity in the past, therefore it is necessary that the European Parliament provide security and supply based on community production as the primary objective of the next reform, without neglecting other contributions such as the fight against climate change.

Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, I concur with Commissioner Cholos that this report is necessary, very necessary, and comes at a timely moment, as the abuses committed by large-scale distribution have been demonstrated, severely disrupting the various links in the food supply chain.

The Bové report, which at times may go too far in its attempt to be overly interventionist, must nevertheless be acknowledged from the perspective of the social market economy that we champion within the European People's Party; I say that it must be acknowledged, as it addresses the legitimate claims of European producers.

Furthermore, it brings transparency to the different parts of the food chain, which is always beneficial, and provides greater possibilities and support for the weaker sectors within that chain to defend themselves, and it undoubtedly supports European consumers so they can learn more about it.

The European food industry might have deserved more consideration within this report, perhaps, and it would have been very beneficial, but this report also includes measures to curb price volatility, which was very necessary.
Measures are also included to ensure fairness for these links in the chain, as requested by the Environment Committee, and to combat the abusive and unfair practices of large-scale distribution.
It is now time to establish a list of abusive practices and for European legislation to prohibit them definitively.
It is also important to include measures to prevent abusive practices through private label products that undermine competition and violate intellectual property law.

For all these reasons, we must support the Bové report and we must support all colleagues who, from the various parliamentary committees—INCO, ENVI, or Agriculture—have demonstrated a commitment to ensuring that this report is finally published and helps European producers thrive.
The alarm bell sounds, and it is true.
And the frustration is also audible, as we are hearing in the interventions of this Plenary, for not having achieved the Millennium Development Goals.
And the truth is that what’s at stake for us is considerable.

Our natural environment is so fragile that if one day the larger fish decided to stop eating the smaller ones, we would have to pay for it all from the pocket of the current generation, with our health and well-being as currency.
The European Union is a leader today in the fight against climate change and has been for some time through pioneering and conservation measures.

However, as demonstrated by the unmet objectives, it appears that there was a lack of will, not only of implementation and coordination, which have also been mentioned here, but also of expansion to go beyond our exceedingly limited special conservation areas.
Of course, biodiversity is not a museum piece that can be enclosed in a segregated area, as it sometimes appears to be, with occasional cursory glances.
Biodiversity thrives and has no boundaries; it traverses the entire Earth with a domino effect in which if one piece falls, they all fall.

I draw attention to the need for a global and more communal will, particularly with regard to land, because subsidiarity, as the sole method for land or forest management, could be one of the new formidable enemies of biodiversity.

Therefore, I draw attention to paragraph 67 and the potential vote that will be cast, and I urge you to reject the second part, because I am convinced that a common policy on land would help preserve the entirety of the territory.

Such a varied, such a diverse Europe—for good and ill—and so lacking in political will among the States, and so in need of ever more European Union, with all the breadth of the term, and what that signifies: more Union also for the land.

Mr. President and Commissioner, first and foremost, I would like to highlight the work of the rapporteur, Ms. Macaban, not only in terms of substance but also in terms of procedure, as she has done so in collaboration with all the shadow rapporteurs.
We also wish to thank the experts from the Spanish Administration for their contribution to this Agreement.

The purpose of this European Union pharmacovigilance system is to strengthen the monitoring, transparency, and communication of drug safety once they have been marketed, particularly with regard to their risk profiles and any adverse reactions that may occur.

It is important to highlight the creation of the European Pharmacovigilance Committee, which will evaluate and issue recommendations to the European Medicines Agency regarding safety issues that may arise with medicines marketed in the European Union.
It is very important the solution that has been reached for the notification to EudraVigilance of suspected adverse reactions, both by Member States and by marketing authorization holders.
EudraVigilance will be the sole source of information, but it will also be notified to the competent authority of the Member State where the adverse reaction is suspected, and this is very important.
It is also important to highlight the possibility that opens for consumers of being able to communicate any adverse reaction, and in this sense, the creation and management by the Agency of a portal.
The European system regarding drug safety, which in turn links to the portals of each Member State, will help improve citizens’ knowledge of the safety of the medications they consume.
And finally, we must not forget that, given that pharmacovigilance plays a fundamental role in the protection of public health, the approval of the Directive and the
This directive and regulation will contribute significantly to this, by improving not only current procedures but also coordination of actions among the various Member States.

Mr. President, I greatly value the opponent's effort to accept some suggestions and, failing that, their defense of copyright, which I share. But the inclusion of the infringing and sanctionable nature of certain exchanges and the

Recognition of sanctioning authority granted to providers, as well as in alternative resolution, the exclusion of mass exchanges as a potential infringement, makes a favorable vote on either report in list impossible.
The Galó report has generated considerable interest and could have been timely, but the underlying debate is too deeply entrenched in the for or against argument surrounding the French law known as.
Adopting a disconnection-from-Internet penalty for offenders, without a genuine European debate that considers the reality of other advancements in national legislations.

I hope we achieve a common position within the Socialist Group and a majority in the European Parliament in the debates and amendments regarding the Commission's proposal, which Commissioner Barnier has announced will shortly be submitted to Parliament.

On this occasion, we will endeavor to reach a more balanced position than currently exists, one that takes into account both the rights of Internet users and the essential respect for intellectual property.
Mr. President, I congratulate those who have worked on this report, on this financial package, especially the officials and the members of this Parliament.
It has taken a financial crisis of enormous dimensions for Europe to awaken.
However, an opportunity has been lost, in part, to strengthen the common institutions of Europe, because, on the one hand, these new supervisory authorities have a scope of competence
limited compared to similar authorities of Member States and it is regrettable that progress has not been made towards an integration similar to that which occurred with the central bank system.
We have made progress, but it is necessary to continue ascending the mountain.

As a member of the Human Rights Commission, as a Spanish and European citizen, and as a victim of terrorism since the terrorist organization ETA murdered my brother and his wife in Seville, I address this Parliament to denounce the Government of Venezuela and its president for having allowed terrorists from

they are being trained in Venezuelan dreams under the orders of the alleged terrorist Cubillas, who works for the government of Hugo Chávez, despite the fact that an international arrest warrant is out for him, which constitutes a serious violation of the fundamental right to security of any European citizen.
I demand that the Government of Spain take decisive action in response to this serious humiliation of all Spaniards.
The Prime Minister cannot remain silent while the Venezuelan ambassador calls our Civil Guard torturers, who have been and will be an example of courage in the fight against ETA.
nor can it turn a blind eye to this growing cooperation between ETA and the FARC on Venezuelan soil, as already denounced by Judge Eloy Velasco.
Zapatero cannot shake hands with a leader like Chávez, who is turning Venezuela into a haven for terrorists.

The president of a country like Spain, where terrorism has caused so much pain, cannot continue to ignore this problem and should offer a response that it deserves and that any ordinary citizen would give if they had the opportunity to do so.
On February fourteenth, two thousand eight, as a Valentine's Day gift, the Conference of Presidents decided that intergroup meetings would convene only on Thursdays.
Since then, we have attempted to resolve this matter.
We did not achieve it.
The intergroups today, Mr. President, must convene on an unsuitable date.
They almost never have rooms and never have interpretation.

Today, I speak not only as president of the Intergroup on Poverty and Human Rights, but with the mandate of the majority of intergroups in this House, and therefore, of the members of this House who are part of those intergroups.
and I solemnly request that the Conference of Presidents reconsider and rescind the decision of February 14, 2008, and revert to the previous status of freedom of the intergroups.
And if you do not, I say kindly as well that we will bring the matter to the Plenary of this House, and it will be decided who within this House is sovereign, which is this Parliament.
Mr. President, International Day against Trafficking in Persons for the Purpose of Exploitation highlighted data that should compel us to act swiftly.
More than ninety percent of prostitution practiced in Europe originates from blackmail and extortion.

And in light of these data, we should ask ourselves if we are doing everything necessary to protect the dignity and integrity of thousands of women whose rights are also protected by the Fundamental Charter that we approved with the Treaty of Lisbon.
because we are not speaking of the oldest profession in the world, but of the only form of slavery that we have not managed to eradicate from old Europe.
Countries like Spain are making significant efforts in this regard, pursuing traffickers, raising public awareness, and facilitating rehabilitation plans for female victims.
but it is not enough.
Europe must be a single space of action and commitment.

The upcoming Equality Directive presents an opportunity to address demand through education and to hinder the ease of access that exists, for example, in the provision for advertising across all types of media, as well as to increase bilateral cooperation with third States to combat this scourge from its origin.
We have an opportunity.
I call upon this Parliament to continue leading the way in the defense of citizens’ rights.
Madam President, we all agree that the diplomatic service represents a historic opportunity for European construction.

But for this, it is necessary to act with a broad vision, because this is not the time for internal struggles over resources that are transferred or withheld in the short term, nor for wars between the various European institutions.
What is now in order, conversely, is to establish a general vision of what the European Union ought to be in the world, that is, to do precisely the opposite of what
that occurred a few days ago, on the occasion of the awarding of the Nobel Peace Prize, where too many voices have been heard from Europe, and not all of them courageous.
Notably, one of the exceptions is the President of this Parliament, Mr. Butchek, who is the author of a brilliant and worthy statement.

Mr. President, the Regulation we are debating today is of vital importance to the future of a sector, the cutlery and related industries, which in my region, the Land of Quixote, specifically in Albacete, represents, in addition to the survival of over eight hundred jobs, an element of identity and a commitment to the future through craftsmanship as a source of job creation.

It is the case that the Medin sealing on knives has long been championed by social groups such as Aprecu and has been contested by the Government of Castilla-La Mancha with the unanimous support of its regional parliament.
A seal of origin that is not interventionism, but rather a commitment to transparency, fair commercial rules, and the fight against unfair competition.

to increase consumers’ decision-making capacity when selecting a product, ensuring they consider not only the final price but also the brand’s quality, the place of origin, or the social conditions under which it is produced.

And, above all, it will represent a new horizon of optimism for many people who are struggling, but who today look at us thinking that we have not been indifferent when it comes to advocating for a fairer trade, yes, but also for adding value to those who, in addition to producing, do so with respect for social rights and the best conditions for European workers.
Therefore, I thank the opponent and Mr. Menéndez del Valle for their political support and their social awareness on this important matter for my region.
Mr. President, let me see if I can bring a little calm to this lively debate.
It is regrettable that certain countries and states comprising the European Union continue to be present at this G20 forum.
Despite this anomaly, which certainly weakens Europe’s image in the world, it would be beneficial if at least a global common position existed in that global forum.
And what, in my opinion, would that common position be?

In my modest opinion, I believe that first, the adoption of a global agreement to address the consequences of the crisis cannot be delayed, and not solely a financial agreement. Secondly, Europe must maintain the euro as a reference currency or, if preferred, as an anchor for

to prevent market turbulence from dragging us down and causing us to repeat the errors committed throughout the 20th century. Thirdly, the euro must serve as a herald of what Europe should represent in the world of democratic values and freedoms.
public
In summary, it must be understood that in the global world, in this global game, loses whoever plays only national cards.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I believe we are in the case of congratulating the rapporteur, Madam Meissner.
There were distinct positions identified, and she has achieved compromise solutions that allow us all to be together on an important matter.

Honorable members, the Transport Committee has decided that all bars should be protected in a similar manner, and to that end, it argues that, otherwise, a situation of unfair competition would arise.

We accept the position of the majority in favor of a legal situation with uniform rules for the entire Union, but it would not save their lordships from pointing out that it also represents a certain lack of equity.
It is evident that the Baltic Sea, the North Sea, and the English Channel are more contaminated areas, and that controls of sulfur limit values should be more rigorous in those cases.
It is necessary to positively value the measures related to ports with regard to solutions for reducing transportation times and handling costs.
In any case, I will not tire of reiterating that at this point we have an outstanding matter.
Without a resolute liberalization of ports, they will not be able to expand the central role they should have within the context of multimodality.
Welcome also, esteemed colleagues, the impetus for a strategy aimed at modifying the specific repercussions of climate change.
I believe this is a positive report that should be voted on.
But we cannot forget that it occurs within the context of a serious disaster, namely that of the Gulf of Mexico.

In that regard, the Commission is urged to assess whether the framework for the revision of the European Maritime Safety Agency Regulation strengthens the Agency's role in prevention inspections and subsequent oil spill cleanup operations.
My personal assessment, Madam Commissioner, is that yes, and that those tasks must be reinforced with whatever mandate is necessary for that purpose.

Mr. President, integrated maritime policy is a cross-cutting, regional, and sectoral policy, which must include fisheries policy and agriculture, and which should not be subordinated to other policies.

We must all respond to environmental and economic problems, both within society at large and within the fishing sector. New technologies, fishing techniques, species development, a plan for a maritime economy.

For greater, more, and better employment, quality supplies, international relations that prevent piracy and promote the governance of our seas—seas that are without barriers and free from sustainability issues, as in the case of Iceland.
This would be working toward an integrated maritime policy, this would be working toward the environment and sustainability.
Mr. President, recently the Church of Our Lady of Sorrows was attacked in Baghdad and fifty-eight people were murdered, the majority of them women and children, solely for being Christians.
Al-Qaeda has proudly claimed responsibility for the massacre.
It is not an isolated incident, but the culmination of persecutions and attacks against Christians in countries with a Muslim majority.
Expulsions in Morocco, threats in Turkey, attacks in India or Nigeria.
In January, six Christians were massacred at the door of a church in Cairo.
Cairo. How long will the complicit silence of Western democracies last?
Fortunately, President Busek has made an official statement.
The High Representative, Ms. Ashton’s, declaration of condemnation has been limited to condemning a terrorist act.
terrorist. Why isn't the motive cited? The condition of the Christians, which is the unequivocal cause of the massacre.
I have heard nothing from Mr. Zapatero, nor have I heard anything from President Erdoğan.
Erdogan, what is the purpose of the Alliance of Civilizations?
I feel sorrow for our paternalism and our cowardice.

Inevitablely, the lamented and misunderstood Oriana Fallaci comes to mind, who announced the arrival of Eurabia and was nearly stoned for having the courage to denounce what is happening in Europe’s complex reality.
Thank you also to the lady commissioner. I share the desire of this Chamber.
I want the proposals from the Europeans to receive the support they deserve in Cancun.
In relation to this debate, it is necessary to underscore the importance of cities in environmental preservation.
There is an agreement among more than zero mayors within the European Union demonstrating the recognition of the problem by these authorities whose actions are decisive if we are to succeed.
Fine words are of no use if we do not have the collaboration of city mayors.
To this end, it is very important to disseminate emissions data, as cities produce nearly eighty percent of greenhouse gases.
Currently, this type of disclosure does not exist, nor, even worse, a common framework for the measurement of these emissions themselves.
There is a non-profit organization called the CO2 Disclosure Project, which already hosts information from thousands of companies, and I believe it could also be utilized by municipalities.
Without their participation, without the participation of these municipalities and their mayors, the environmental action will dissipate into smoke, the very smoke from which we wish to escape.

Mr. President, some have stated that the condemnation of Morocco is too lenient, given the magnitude of the human rights repression in the Western Sahara, in which Morocco is nothing more than an occupying country without sovereignty or legal title whatsoever.
But the important thing is the message that all of Europe and this Parliament can no longer tolerate its violence.
Yesterday, I was speaking about the International Court of Justice in this very Parliament.

The international community, which sadly failed to prevent the genocides in Rwanda, Yugoslavia, and Darfur, hopes to avoid, however, the one in Western Sahara, and that we do not have to witness it before another court, also in The Hague, as I was saying, but this time for war crimes.
Mr. President, Commissioner, the Directive approved in 2009 was a success because it updates the regulatory framework governing toy safety.
It is a significant step in the right direction because it indicates the path forward, but it is not enough.
We must always be vigilant and attentive to ensure that toys marketed do not jeopardize the safety and health of children.
All toys on the market must comply with current legislation.

We must review and improve surveillance mechanisms to detect hazardous toys, whether due to substances considered toxic under ECMR regulations, fragrances, or other hazardous substances such as HPA compounds.
It is necessary that the guidelines to be followed be clearer regarding the warning concerning the minimum age and the dangers arising from improper use.
The recommended age for toys must be based on studies of children’s behaviors.
We must be capable of adapting our regulations to scientific advancements, supported by solid studies, and be more rigorous in the monitoring of the market and the importation of toys.
It is necessary to work together and strengthen cooperation among Member States, and to rely on the joint efforts of customs authorities to control the route of imported toys.
Citizens are preparing to do their holiday shopping, and we must assure them that the products they purchase meet all safety requirements.
I believe that in this debate we have seen clearly that we all agree to support the objective of this report.
The various political groups have expressed their support for this Directive, which offers greater protection to victims.
Therefore, I ask, what impediment exists to approving this instrument?
I repeat, what fears are there that something as necessary and straightforward as protecting victims equally across Europe should finally become a reality?
Hoping that this Parliament will largely approve this report, I address the Council and the Commission, reminding them that we have
Having overcome the legal hurdles in our negotiations, I applaud the Commission's recognition of our work, as we recognize the work it will undertake in the future.

We must not exclude ourselves, but rather assist each other, by approving this more concrete instrument today, and tomorrow the broader package of measures to aid victims that the Commission will present, with which I pledge to collaborate.
Therefore, let us be brave and responsible today, and let us help all those who have the right to live in a safer Europe.
Let us help everyone, I repeat, whether men, women, or children.
Let us help those who look to us today, expecting us to give them a better life, a life that restores their freedom, their safety, and, above all, their dignity.

Madam President, the European People’s Party Group will vote enthusiastically in favor of this report, and my congratulations first to the rapporteurs, the Commission, and the Council for this agreement.
We coined, ladies and gentlemen, the term “democratic deficit” in the 1980s.

With him, we wanted to say that within the European Union, decisions were made solely by the Council of Ministers on the proposal of the Commission, and this Parliament was consulted only for its opinion.
The battle of this Parliament since the 1980s, through the Treaty of Maastricht, of Amsterdam, of Nice, the Constitutional Treaty, and the Treaty of Lisbon, has been

to bridge that democratic deficit. And I believe that with the Treaty of Lisbon, with the new powers of the European Parliament, with the participation of national Parliaments, we have achieved that objective.
And we conclude today with this citizen legislative initiative, which, in the work of the Convention, was due to the good cooperation between national parliaments and the European Parliament.

And I want to recall here the names of Jürgen Mayer, our German social democratic colleague, and Alain Lamassur, who were the ones who brought that initiative to the plenary session of the Convention and ensured its approval.
Therefore, I believe we have completed the circle, Madam President.
I believe that today, when we vote on the initiative, we will have brought about, placed on the table, the death certificate of the concept of democratic deficit.
It is now our turn, esteemed members, to act responsibly, and today we also have the opportunity to do so.
By voting on the EU budget, we will fulfill what is expected of us – a responsible Parliament and a co-decision-making Parliament.
I believe it is a good day for Europe, ladies and gentlemen.

Mr. President, in January of two thousand twelve, four hundred Spanish egg producers could disappear, approximately thirty percent of the total number in my country, with the loss of a production of three hundred zero tons of eggs.

And the European Union could cease producing those eighty million eggs, those two million tonnes, and we would only manage to have them covered by imports from third countries whose animal welfare standards are far lower than those of the European Union if we do not act with great intelligence.
This 1999 Directive, which mandates an increase in the space allocated to battery cages for laying hens, requires us to act with intelligence and a forward-looking vision, because if not.

We will only succeed in weakening European production and giving extra, commercial opportunities, to third countries where the space per bird is infinitely worse than the current space we have in the European Union.

It is a Directive that requires enormous efforts from European producers. In Spain alone, we can see that the cost rises to approximately six hundred million euros, but we must also not forget that it has an economic impact that extends to the ovoproduct industry and the food industry in general.

I therefore request the support of the honourable members for the Popular Group’s amendment to the second paragraph, wherein it is requested to seek a solution, at least, for responsible industrial operations that are proceeding with the transformation of their businesses and which, by January of two thousand twelve, will be nearing completion.

We must support them in transforming those facilities and allow them time to finalize that process, thereby preventing irreparable harm to the farms and avoiding a sudden situation of scarcity in the community market, consequently increasing prices for consumers.
It is a matter of respecting the Directive, of giving an opportunity to the egg and ovoproduct industry, while also respecting animal welfare rights and the consumers’ right to a reasonable price.

Mr. President, I believe it is only right to thank the rapporteurs, particularly Mrs. Grostet and Mrs. Dagmar Ronberend from my own Group, for the work they have done to remove a regulation from deadlock and render it useful, because that work has enabled the inclusion of the right to public health as a legal basis.

and to have a new orientation that allows us to lay the groundwork to guarantee citizens the safety and quality they choose at each moment, particularly because it also enables a clear regulation of the role of States, both those of origin that must make the payment and those in which treatment is received.

But I believe that we should not feel satisfied with that alone, but rather that this must be the beginning of a much greater advance that makes, as Mrs. Romperen said, this Directive a mere formality, because the level of equality achieved in all States renders unnecessary the displacement of each citizen to each country.

And in that struggle, we must obtain a standard that better guarantees the rights of citizens in relation to the care they are entitled to receive, benefits, accessibility, and safety, than the mere right they already have to mobility between States.
Equality is what will move Union forward; if not, we will be taking very small steps.
Madam President, the Spanish Socialist Delegation has voted in favor, as has the rest of our group, but I would not leave here quietly without making clear my concern, because this Directive includes
the issue of organ transplants against the opinion held by the Environment Committee as a result of the Council's persistent insistence on including transplants in this Directive.

I hope that this inclusion does not diminish the effectiveness of the good legislation we approved in this very session, both with the Transplant Directive and the Action Plan, very recently and with near unanimous support.

I caution that we will be vigilant to ensure that this inclusion does not diminish the excellent work performed by organizations as successful as the Spanish National Transplantation Organization and, of course, with that intention of saving twenty thousand lives that we had both in the Transplant Directive and in the Action Plan, which, I repeat, we approved here.
Therefore, I make it clear and state that we will continue to monitor compliance with this Directive in that regard.
Mr. President, today is also European Day for Sexual Health, as well.
Esteemed colleagues, the data are concerning. The World Health Organization estimates that over three hundred million people unknowingly contract a sexually transmitted infection each year.

In Europe, as the European Forum for Sexual Health warns, the increase in unwanted pregnancies among adolescents is concerning due to an excessive deficit of education and information among our young people.

Even, as the Commission points out, there exist various and diverse inequalities in access to sexual health services across European countries, and within those countries, according to citizens’ income levels.
To combat all of this, a European strategy is necessary.

Only five Member States have plans in this regard, but in all of them, it has been possible to reduce the number of unintended pregnancies, the transmission of sexually transmitted diseases, and also the number of abortions.

A common strategy that prioritizes prevention within the educational sphere, expands information policies, increases efforts in family planning, and facilitates accessibility to contraceptive methods.
A cross-cutting and ambitious strategy, free of taboos, to guarantee the rights of every citizen to sexual health under the highest standards of safety and well-being.
In a period of heightened social tensions, one cannot help but warmly welcome the significant social agreement reached in Spain between the Government, trade unions, and employers’ associations.
