This agreement is exemplary for Europe, where such milestones have not been seen for some time.

It is also important to consider the reasoning of Cándido Méndez, one of the principal protagonists of that Spanish agreement, who attended the meeting of the Economic and Social Council in Brussels last Tuesday, February eighth.
Cándido then insisted on the necessity of extending the agreement to a European scale and on the need to include the voice and initiative of trade unions in this our Europe.
So it must be.

Mr. President, setting aside the differences in matters of terrorism and immigration, I have observed that the European Union, unfortunately, moves in response to emergency situations, such as those of a serious nature.

an attack or a massive influx of immigrants like the one currently occurring in Lampedusa, where the exodus of Tunisian citizens toward the Italian coastlines could result in a chronicle of a foretold death.

The journey of hope can end in a cursed journey and weigh upon our consciences, upon those of all those who witness these continuous, uncontrolled flows and do not say enough with sufficient authority.
When it happens, we will clutch our heads in dismay, but the next day we will forget.

European citizens have both the obligation and the right to know the truth: that the Mediterranean strategy is not working, and that a common immigration policy will remain a dream as long as European countries do not commit to sufficient economic resources to make Frontex effective.
Talking costs nothing, but action is required.
Do they genuinely believe that Frontex can currently guarantee the security of European borders?
I believe not.

And let us hope that the citizens of Tunisia, Egypt, and other Maghreb countries do not decide to seek a better future en masse in Europe, but rather in their own countries, because that is what they have fought for, and we must contribute to helping them.
Therefore, solidarity, responsibility, but above all, truth when discussing a common European migration policy, one that is today more necessary than ever.

Madam President, it has already been stated that the backbone of pension systems in Europe is and should remain the public system, because this is the only system that guarantees cohesion and the only one, moreover, that reduces the risks of poverty in our society.

It is striking that in OECD countries, the highest levels of income equality for citizens are found in the realm of pensions, or that, due to the crisis, private pensions lost only twenty percent of their value in 2008, and that they continue, to this day, far from the solvency levels required.

All of this demonstrates that, at a time of unavoidable reforms, the sustainability of our pension system must be addressed in a transversal manner, taking into account, among other factors, ambitious policies regarding birth rates or work-life balance.

Ambitious policies regarding access to and retention in employment, or even immigration policies based on integration that also, from a demographic perspective, guarantees the sustainability of our pensions.
Finally, I regret that the text does not set limits on the abuse of scholarships within companies, as these are generally excluded from all forms of social security contributions.

In my view, this is essential for an entire new generation of workers to whom, if they are being required to contribute more to secure a decent pension, it would also be necessary to make it less arduous for them to access a decent job.

Mr. President, Commissioner, we find ourselves at a pivotal moment in the construction of the future cohesion policy, which, following the entry into force of the Treaty of Lisbon, focuses not only on economic and social aspects, but also on the territorial dimension.
Territorial cohesion seeks a harmonious development among territories to ensure that their citizens can maximize the benefits of their unique territorial characteristics.
However, to achieve this objective, it is also necessary to advance cooperation between regions of the Union facing similar challenges and issues.

This is the objective pursued by the European Union's Strategy for the Atlantic region: a common perspective for addressing the common challenges faced by the States of the region, including marine research, maritime surveillance, and environmental and economic challenges.

To achieve our objectives, it is necessary to adopt an integrated strategic approach that is aligned with the 2020 Strategy and the policies of the European Union for the period following 2013, particularly with regional policy and maritime policy.
But, Honourable Members, above all, it is necessary that this strategy be based on a renewed multilevel governance, founded on a closer involvement of public authorities.
regional and local, Member States, the European Union, and private sector stakeholders and civil society organizations, including interregional organizations and networks.

It is a very significant day to discuss equality between men and women, because we celebrate International Women’s Day, remembering those who, one hundred years ago, fought for labor and economic rights and for women’s suffrage.
We have made significant progress in these one hundred years, but much remains to be done, and true equality is still a dream, and the discrimination of women is a real fact.

I believe that each of us, men and women, can do much more to achieve the true emancipation of women, because there are many women in the world whose right to live is threatened, whose dignity is violated, and whose freedom is denied.
Allow me, on this International Women's Day, to express my support and my hope to all the women who in the North African Revolution are fighting for their democratic rights.
Because a woman cannot be worth half as much as a man, neither in Arab countries nor anywhere else in the world.
Therefore, we are of equal value and deserve the same.
And I will continue fighting to achieve it, and as long as that equality does not exist, International Women's Day will persist.
Although there are many who do not want to see it, it is a reality that women earn half as much as men, and that domestic violence primarily affects women and children.
And I repeat, we must continue to denounce all those events in this Parliament, and certainly, I promise I will continue working.
Mr. President, I wish to express my agreement with the opinion of the deputies who have spoken this morning here and who insist on respect for Parliament and the Commission.
Therefore, my modest affirmative vote will depend on whether the European Council is willing to acknowledge the role of the institutions mentioned.
because the new mechanism, concerning which we are speaking, must be an important component of the economic governance led by a European Union
capable of ensuring coherence between the common economic policy, which must set clear, precise, and limited objectives, and this stability instrument.

That is to say, we must avoid at all costs this endeavor in which we are engaged from ending up in the intergovernmental channel, which is a dead end or the channel of dominance by a few states, because all of this would frustrate the reform.
Dear colleagues, Europe is built stone by stone, and this one reinforces and balances this delicate edifice.
There remain essential points to improve, therefore we must return the report to the Commission.
It does not end here, therefore, the parliamentary process of this report.
The initial proposal was poor.
That is how consumer associations at both the national and European levels told us.
And, in particular, my esteem for the work of the Consumer Union of Asturias and its president, the indefatigable Dacio Alonso.
We have succeeded in ensuring the general principle of maximum harmonization of the former Article Four was rejected.

It must be stated clearly that maximum harmonization when establishing the same protection in all Member States would represent a reduction in the protection afforded to many consumers, as there exists in various countries a greater tradition of consumer rights protection.

I would like to emphasize, in any case, that it is essential to ensure that the list of abusive contractual clauses is not exhaustive, allowing each Member State to increase the number of clauses it considers unacceptable and invalid in contracts with consumers.

Shift the burden of proof to the individual clauses, so it is the merchants who must demonstrate that the clauses deviating from what is generally established have been individually negotiated, and that the contractual clauses are expressed in a clear and comprehensible manner.
We remain opposed to the establishment of maximum harmonization with respect to abusive clauses.
The Eurobarometer indicates that 79% of merchants believe that full harmonization in this area will have little or no effect on their activities abroad.
Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, allow me first to congratulate the rapporteur, Mr. Schwab, and Ms. Gerhardt for the excellent work performed.
and a general reflection.
It is not that protectionism is increasing, but rather that the aim is to avoid reducing rights already existing in some of the Member States.
Because, if we want and pursue establishing a genuine internal market for relations between businesses and consumers, we must
Establish, simultaneously, a balance between the high level of protection afforded to consumer rights and the defense of corporate competitiveness.
This balance requires agreeing to a minimum harmonization and allowing Member States to maintain or adopt additional regulations that enhance consumer protection.
We cannot allow the adoption of a community rule to mean the lack of protection for many consumers and users.
I welcome the improvement in negotiations within the European Parliament, but I wish to emphasize that rights already established should not be curtailed.

Mr. President, many experts are telling us that the next crisis may be an energy crisis, and that, furthermore, we are either not doing the necessary work to avoid it or we are not doing so at the necessary speed to avoid it.
This coming Saturday, the World Forum for Nature issues a call for everyone to make a small gesture in the interest of sustainability.
Many citizens will turn off their lights for an hour, and many public administrations will follow suit.
but it is not sufficient.
Europe cannot continue to depend on energies that are not its own, that are distant, or on insecure energies.
We must help the nations build a new energy model in which renewable energies are the heart of the new one.
We must also support the raising of awareness regarding new consumption guidelines, because, without any doubt, renewables and efficiency are the keys to future sustainability.

Finally, I want to make a call to all countries of the Union to join that call, that willingness of five of them, including Spain, to increase CO2 emission reductions to thirty percent, because in doing so we would demonstrate that Europe, in addition to being a leader in freedom and rights, is also a leader in its commitment to the sustainability of the planet.
Madam President, most of the times I have spoken in this Parliament, I have done so to denounce violence against women, and once again I am here to combat it.

I must say that I not only do not tire of it, but I consider it essential to continue speaking publicly about this violation of human rights, as there is no cause that can be defended without a platform, and this Parliament is the best.

I have the platform available to defend all those women who suffer daily abuse and who need us, legislators, to compel the States to punish aggressors, according to the severity of the crime, and also to assist the victims.

When it is estimated that one-quarter of European women have experienced gender-based violence at least once in their lives, and that children to the same extent, I believe it is impossible not to call for greater commitment, as recognized by the Commission in its Action Plan.

I believe it is necessary to continue emphasizing, time and again, the need to protect victims, as we already did with the European Order for the Protection of Victims, of which I was rapporteur and which I hope will become a reality as soon as possible.
This report has enjoyed considerable consensus and support from the outset, which demonstrates that, when addressing domestic violence—affecting all family members—
Families, children, older adults, women, and men—should not be a source of political opportunism, as it is to the honor of us all to advance the solution of this social scourge.
First, one must not remain silent, and second, one must begin to work, for, although we have been discussing gender-based violence for decades, we have not been able to reduce the number of deaths.

Something must be amiss, and therefore it is time to abandon demagoguery and move from words to actions, providing the necessary assistance and response so that women can live with dignity and security.
security, that all victims know that I will always be here to continue lending them my voice until we all manage to defeat this
terrible enemy that tragically ends the lives of so many innocents. I say enough, enough now, and I ask all of you to say it with me.
Mr. President, Commissioner, I concur with you that we must listen to citizens and regain trust in the European project.
Therefore, today could be a great day for Europe and the construction of European society.

Because with the approval of these reports, we are not only moving forward towards the reactivation of the single market, a key element in the face of the current economic crisis, but we are also responding to the demands of citizens who are calling for progress towards greater Europe and the strengthening of social rights.

Europe must respond to new global challenges and ensure that the European economy becomes a social market economy, highly competitive, that generates sustainable growth with more and better employment.

But this objective must be based on the insertion of a social clause in all legislation related to the internal market, placing citizens at the center of our attention and priority, and strengthening their social rights.
Finally, I would like to request that the Commission present these proposals as soon as possible.
Mr. President, blue tongue has been a constant threat to our livestock and, with it, to our public health as well.

a disease against which we fought through an activated vaccine, the use of which entails the creation of restricted zones for animal circulation, because the use of these vaccines can provoke unwanted virus circulation in uninfected animals.

For these reasons, vaccination was limited to areas where animals infected with the disease had previously been found, thereby creating a double disadvantage for livestock farmers: on the one hand, the disease itself, and on the other, the restrictions.

But all these problems appear to be avoidable through the new inactivated vaccine, which, in addition to preventing the disruptions that can be caused in the domestic livestock market, allows for the development of new and broader strategies—which is truly important—of prevention in the fight against this disease.
For all of these reasons, it is of vital importance to this sector that we modify the Directive to permit its use, and that we do so as soon as possible.

Honorable members, compliance with what our Treaties stipulate, particularly concerning the correlation tables, cannot serve as an excuse for this regulation not to come into effect before summer, because any delay would only harm livestock farmers.

Mr. President, firstly, I would like to thank the Petitions Committee for the work it has done following the complaint presented by FEPEX, which is the Spanish Organisation of Fruit and Vegetable Producers and Exporters, based on the report published in 2007 by OLAF, the European Anti-Fraud Office.

I believe the conclusions of that report are exceedingly clear and sufficiently justify the European Commission having taken action long ago to clarify the functioning of the pricing system, at least with regard to the tomato sector.

However, the Commission has not only failed to intervene to resolve potential loopholes arising from the current Entry Price Regulation, but has also negotiated a new Agricultural Agreement with Morocco without previously addressing the shortcomings of the existing import regime.

Honorable Members, it is now time for the European Commission to take its responsibilities seriously and begin investigating where fraud occurs, and ultimately request the recovery of unpaid customs duties.
I believe that a new agreement with Morocco should in no way be ratified without resolving the details that we have outlined.

Our objective is not to impede the signing of international agreements, but rather to ensure that such agreements do not seriously harm the interests of European productions and that the rules stipulated in those agreements are respected.

Regarding the new Agreement with Morocco, the European fruit and vegetable sector only requests guarantees that the effective implementation of the agreed-upon measures will be carried out, and this is only possible through the reform of the current import pricing regime.
Until we have a new entry price system, we will not be able to have a new agreement with Morocco.
We will not be able to ratify that agreement which the Commission has already closed.

Furthermore, if control is the responsibility of the Member States, then a significant economic effort would be required of those states; however, it is also true that for a long time we have been calling for a European customs border system, analogous to that of the United States, to ensure that effective control.

Mr. President, Commissioner, addressing this report in Parliament has been complex, primarily because it involves these measures that require the approval of the World Trade Organization and the Commission’s preliminary proposal sent to Parliament differs from the one sent to Geneva.

We believe it is necessary to assist Pakistan. We understand that exceptional trade preferences may be granted, provided they take into account the sensitivities of the [Union/Organization - *depending on context*].
the European industry and, particularly, the textile sector, which in regions like the Valencian Community in Spain are severely suffering the consequences of the crisis.

However, this report has allowed us to verify that the measures that can be taken within the framework of international trade likely cannot be addressed with the urgency these acts require, and therefore we must learn from this experience for the future.
Helping Pakistan, yes, but not with the Commission’s original proposal, as it does not account for the effects on the European industry regarding the implementation deadlines for sensitive products.
It would even delay the implementation of these measures, as they would not align with the pending text expected to be approved by the WTO; we would be out of time.
Therefore, we consider it unacceptable to maintain this proposal and believe that we will have to vote against it.
Thank you very much, Mr. President. I would like to begin my remarks by congratulating everyone who has made reaching an agreement possible.

It is an agreement that we should all congratulate ourselves on, as it affects the daily lives of all citizens. However, with the constructive spirit that characterizes me, I would like to make a few observations.
Firstly, I would like to draw attention to the importance of providing accurate, relevant, but above all, comprehensible and consistent information.
for consumers regarding the components of textile products. Extensive information will be of no use if citizens are subsequently unable to decipher it.
We have achieved a positive, necessary, but insufficient step. We should advance further and protect citizens who could be more vulnerable.

Distinguished members, it is imperative to establish a European system of size labeling based on body measurements, because the first thing we encounter when purchasing an item of clothing is the size.
Therefore, we should be much more ambitious and seek size harmonization.
Mr. President, three observations regarding the situation created around the cucumbers.
I am of German descent and have a great fondness for that country, but it is evident that German authorities have acted with undue haste and imprudence in this case.

On the other hand, if we analyze the European performance, we observe that the action undertaken by the Food Safety Authority and by the Commission has been lackluster, quite muted, and imprecise; it has failed to coordinate or direct.
Thirdly, those harmed are entitled to swift economic compensation.
However, for the time being, I propose to this Parliament that we organize in Brussels or here in Strasbourg a large exhibition of European gastronomy based precisely on the cucumber.
One must reclaim lost honor—an expression pleasing to the German writer Heinrich Bell—one must reclaim the lost honor of cucumber producers.
Europe is the appropriate setting for it.
Mr. President, it is imperative to express my sincere sorrow for the twenty-three victims already deceased, twenty-two in Germany and one in Sweden.
And this crisis must be said to be the most conclusive proof that the European Union needs to improve, and significantly, its food alert system and its internal coordination.
The member states involved have demonstrated slowness, ineffectiveness, and inaction; and at this point, even after twenty-three deaths, we still do not know where the problem originates.

The European Commission must seriously reflect on the problems caused by its irresponsible actions or inaction during times of crisis such as the present, leading to economic ruin and the destruction of previously viable jobs.

destabilization, unemployment, helplessness, and, of course, a health crisis with exceedingly high health risks to the population. Because while you, from the Commission, were echoing irresponsible statements by regional authorities

very ill-informed and quite irresponsible [German women], with names and surnames of Spanish farms, meanwhile the population remained unknowingly exposed to the bacteria, believing they were avoiding it; the citizens were more exposed than ever to consuming something that could harm them.

The European Commission should today, at the Council of Agriculture being held in Luxembourg at two o’clock in the afternoon, propose to the ministers that a portion of the two hundred million euros existing as unutilized carryover funds from the common agricultural policy be used.
those two hundred million euros to repair as much as possible the damage caused.

To that end, it is necessary to seek a legal framework that allows for it, a legal framework that has been found on other occasions, such as in the cases of mad cow disease or dioxins, and which should now be found.
Therefore, Commissioners, Ministers, today in Luxembourg you must rise to the level of your responsibility.

German authorities, moreover, given the irresponsible accusations made, should support this economic solution, undoubtedly, and from the outset, and also finance, with their own funds, campaigns to re-establish consumer confidence lost in horticultural produce.

Mr. President, Commissioner, nothing we do here or in the European Union will bring back the dead, and I hope that what is being done will prevent further losses and halt the chain of suffering endured by those who had done nothing to deserve it.

We do not know the causes, certainly, but we do know certain things that we must call by their name. There has been negligence in political actions, and there has been negligence in the German federal government. It cannot act as if Hamburg were a city-state of another continent.

The arrogance displayed by Mrs. Merkel and her Minister of Health in addressing other states with unusual frequency, if they had translated this into diligence and effectiveness in coordinating, some of the things that have happened would not have occurred.

And that negligence has had criminal consequences for a State that has been the Spanish State and for its most important sector, agriculture, and has led to family ruin for thousands of people and small business owners, and has discredited the economy for a long time.
I request that you go to the Council and demand full compensation for those affected, since we cannot ask for the lives of the deceased.
and that the control systems be reviewed.
and that responsibility be demanded of Mrs. Merkel.
and that he be asked for less arrogance and more diligence.
and that he be held responsible for damages he has caused.
You cannot ignore the fact that Hamburg is in your state.
He cannot ignore his responsibilities.
It cannot shelter under a decentralized and federal state to inflict the damage it has caused.

A little more humility, a little more sound management, and a little less conservatism would have served well to prevent this crisis from slipping through their fingers, and to ensure that Spain and other farmers in the south would not have to suffer its grievous consequences.
Review the controls, review the alert systems, and demand accountability, because we are requesting it of you, Commissioner, of the Council, and of the German State, here in Spain.
Mr. President, we are facing a public health problem, a pandemic, as the Commissioner has said, and in response, someone has been sought as a scapegoat, if not the cause itself.

The system has not functioned. We have twenty-two fatalities, one six hundred affected, and we do not know the cause three weeks later. And, appealing to a principle of precaution—I repeat, without scientific basis—Spain is being blamed.
Honorable members of parliament, Spanish cucumbers were not contaminated.
contaminated, they were not contaminated. I repeat this because contrary accounts have been heard here.
But so you can see the importance of what these words have generated, three hundred jobs could be affected, a loss of confidence.
An epidemic knows no borders.

I agree with you, Commissioner, you do not know borders. We are demanding accountability for what has not been done, for what we must do immediately, because Germany currently has a risk problem, it has a higher number of affected individuals, but Spain is not to blame.
We demand compensation.
What is important and what unites us here today are the victims, because no one should feel as unprotected as European consumers do today.
And it is out of respect for the victims that we need clarity and accountability.

It is my responsibility to report to German authorities that they unjustly and hastily accused Spanish cucumbers and, specifically, the cooperatives of Málaga and Almería—model agricultural operations—which will not recover from these accusations.
Thousands of families without work wonder why, why they need an answer, and above all, what their future will be, not only in Andalusia, but throughout agricultural Europe.

Therefore, and trusting that experts will swiftly find a solution, I demand that the Commission, when it goes to speak with the Council today, request economic, immediate, and moral measures for all producers who, from Andalusia and from across Europe, look towards us with indignation, but with hope.
Rather than prioritizing research and European collaboration, German authorities have defamed and harmed cucumber producers and others.
And still, no one in Germany has resigned or offered reparations commensurate with the damage caused.
It is Germany that has a serious credibility problem.
The treatment of the southern countries by Mrs. Merkel regarding agriculture and also finance is intolerable.
Someone said that Merkel was a disciple of Adenauer and Kohl.
None of that lacks credibility. Morality.
Mr. President, it is no coincidence that Spain, Italy, Greece, Ireland, Portugal, and perhaps another country share our reservations about readily accepting the so-called Eurovision.

The coincidence is that criticism arises from our condition as peripheral countries, ultimately meaning we will be the ones to pay this singular levy that will be collected by the States of the European Union with central geographical positioning.
The rationale that inspires the eurocomic is fraught with significant contradictions, and the supporting discourse grows weaker with each passing day.

Although the rationality of internalizing external costs is accepted as a starting point, ultimately it does not hold that, in order to alleviate congestion, only high-tonnage vehicles should be penalized, leaving passenger cars exempt, in the same way that the long-standing principle of "polluter pays" is applied with evident discrimination.

On the other hand, ladies and gentlemen, the Eurovignette, which was conceived as a source of funding for infrastructure, will ultimately allocate only fifteen percent to the financing of trans-European networks, and not in a mandatory manner.

but as a simple recommendation, so that the minister of finance of the moment will allocate the funds raised to the purpose he deems most convenient for the interests of his country within the broad chapter of infrastructure.
The final result will be nothing more than another blow to the transportation of goods by road, which, as things stand today, is the only mode enabling the internal market.
This is the reality, ladies and gentlemen, a reality that is far more stark in a crisis economic situation.

In that sense, the competitiveness of European products in global markets cannot permit experiments that may contribute to further deteriorating the precarious situation of the European economy through the imposition of new additional costs.

The food crisis, recklessly placed upon Spanish products, has produced an unjust penalty and substantial losses for those penalized by the euro vignette – transport companies and farmers of primary crops.
Those are the reasons, esteemed members, for which the Spanish Delegation of the European People’s Party will vote against this draft directive.

You will all, dear colleagues, understand that upon assuming the presidency of the session, I must express my sorrow and consternation at the passing of Jorge Semprún, which occurred a few hours ago at the age of eighty-seven.

At Jorges Emprun, we commemorate the individual who was once imprisoned in the Buchenwald concentration and extermination camp, the fighter against the forces of Nazism in France and against the Franco dictatorship in my country, Spain.
We also celebrate the remarkable, committed writer, a particular contributor to our program, The European Book of the Year, and we also celebrate the convinced Europeanist politician.

I mourn his death, also, as a colleague and friend of his, and I will ask President Buzek to convey a message of deep sorrow and solidarity to his family and the Government of Spain, which I am sure we all share here.
creation of an economic governance space governed by the principles of federalism adapted to the European construction.
We cannot continue to turn a blind eye.
It is inconsistent to have a single currency while simultaneously lacking the fiscal and financial instruments that such a currency demands.
Specifically, therefore, we need the issuance of European debt, a resounding no to competition between the debt issuances of the Member States, the creation of a genuine European public treasury, the
harmonization of tax policies that guarantee the equality of citizens, combat tax fraud, and help to define a progressive European social policy based on effective public services.
These ideas, it will be said, are elementary.
But they must be repeated and repeated because no one listens to them.
And precisely because of not listening, those dark times of which the poet Bertolt Brecht spoke are unfolding.

Mr. President, Commissioner, Ladies and Gentlemen, the current economic and financial crisis we are experiencing highlights the need for regional policy as the best instrument for reducing development disparities between regions and states.
At the same time, we can reclaim the positive image of Europe that citizens have lately only associated with stringent austerity plans and social cuts.

The future cohesion policy, a pillar of European solidarity and social justice, must take the following priorities into account: first, to strengthen social cohesion and integrate the challenges posed by the 2020 Strategy; second, to consider the needs and characteristics

geographical characteristics of the regions, especially those that are most disadvantaged. Third, maintain the principle of gradualism in the allocation of funds so that regions do not abandon the convergence objective, avoiding abrupt changes in the provision of aid. And fourth, foster a system
equitable.
Finally, ladies and gentlemen, authorities are implementing stringent austerity measures.
Therefore, the Union’s support is necessary.
I hope the Council takes good note.

In defense of fundamental rights, I urge the responsible institutions to review the designation of San Sebastián as European Capital of Culture, because I believe it was chosen based on a political criterion, which constitutes discrimination against the other candidate cities.

The President of the Tribunal stated that I was selected to support the peace process and, as far as I am aware, in Spain there exists a terrorist organization called ETA that, to this day, has not abandoned arms and which, two months ago, managed to have its political wing, Bildu, govern, among other municipalities, San Sebastián.

I do not believe that from Europe we should give such a powerful voice to those who do not condemn terrorist violence and will engage in propaganda to apportion blame between victims and perpetrators.
assassins, where is the right to freedom and to dignity?
Certainly, not in San Sebastián, where our colleagues, such as Mayor Oreja, Iturgaiz, Salva, or myself, must be escorted.
I believe in a culture of life, not in a culture of discarding children.
Gentlemen, can there be true culture without freedom?
No and a thousand times no.
And when San Sebastián is a free city for all, may it present its candidacy again, and in the meantime, may they learn the culture of respect for those who think differently.
Because tomorrow they might deserve it, but today, with Batasuna and its heirs in the institutions, they do not deserve it.
Mr. President, firstly, I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs for the fruitful collaboration they have provided in drafting this document.
And the same I say with respect to the other deputy colleagues of the Commission of this Parliament.
Sixty years ago, the European Coal and Steel Community was created. Few things are better to commemorate this event than to debate now about energy infrastructures in Europe.

Today, the European Union has clearly defined the objectives of its Common European Internal Market policy, the promotion of renewable energies as a means or instrument in the fight against climate change, security of supply, and diversification of its sources.

In the Treaty of Lisbon, Title Twenty-One has been dedicated to energy, where these commitments I have just mentioned are formulated, and furthermore, the promotion of interconnection of energy networks.
The objective of the report we have prepared is to rectify energy infrastructures that, in the opinion of the European Commission, have become outdated and poorly interconnected.

Thus, for example, we observe a spectacular increase in electricity generation from wind power in the North Sea and the Baltic Sea, alongside the immense potential of renewable energy in Southern Europe.
Europe and in North Africa, with the problems stemming from large-scale electricity storage, with the recharging needs of electric vehicles, among many other pressing issues.
All of this is impossible to face today if we do not devise new networks and new connections, both within the European Union and with third countries.

It is therefore, in these coming years, a matter of advancing the determination of necessary infrastructure, establishing the criteria that will allow for the selection of projects of European interest.

b, eliminating energy islands,
c, ensuring the execution of these projects within reasonable timeframes and arbitrating solutions to the contentious issue of the
procedures for authorization and licenses in the Member States, d, ensuring financing that attracts and drives private investment, without prejudice to public support that may be necessary.
Energy efficiency and savings, as well as smart grids, are central ingredients in the new design incorporated into the report, because we have
I believe that by reducing energy demand, dependence on imports can be diminished, with the consequent effect on infrastructure needs.
A primary concern of this report from the outset has been the processing of licenses and authorizations intended to allow for the execution of the necessary works.
currently, they are prolonged.
and are perpetuated by the opposition of populations to seeing towers or installations of another type grow in their vicinity.

To resolve this conflict, consideration has been given to providing early information to citizens and establishing a warning system in the event that the authorities of a State do not address a request within a reasonable timeframe.
We face ambitious goals requiring the participation of all.
In this regard, companies within the sector are essential, rightfully calling for a stable regulatory framework, the best way to secure financing for their endeavors.

Mr. President, Mr. President, regarding the Directive on the Rights of Victims of Crime, including terrorism, and as a Spaniard who has directly suffered the cruelty of the terrorist organization ETA, I wish to thank President Busek for his support of my country and its victims.

I understand the satisfaction of many regarding this new statement from ETA, but I must remind you that we cannot yet celebrate, because to this day, they have not handed over the weapons, nor have they dissolved, nor have they apologized to their victims.
It is also important for your Lordships to know that in Spain we do not need to reach any peace between two factions because there has been no war.
My brother, Alberto Jiménez Becerril, murdered by ETA in Seville alongside his wife, was not returning from war; he was going home to his three children, who would never see him again.
We have the obligation to explain to my brother’s children that their parents were better than those who murdered them.
If we accept an ending without victors or vanquished, we will be teaching those children that political objectives are achieved through killing.

Therefore, I request the support of this Chamber so that it is not deceived by the terrorists of this group and their accomplices, and so it listens to the sincere voices of the victims, who desire nothing more than the peace born of justice.

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen colleagues, this crisis is teaching us a great deal, but there is one that appears to me to be of particular importance, and that is the following.
It will be necessary in the future to modify the Treaties in order to fundamentally reform the decision-making procedure and the adoption of agreements within the European institutions.
The diabolical system currently in place is slow, frustrating, and, moreover, full of whims.

Therefore, it is necessary to adapt and update the system for the recognition of professional qualifications to reflect the realities of the labor market and the demands and needs of both professionals and consumers.

The Commission’s forthcoming proposal should encompass greater transparency and simplification in the rules governing the recognition of professional qualifications, an assessment of compensatory measures to address existing problems, and a greater

Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, we are confronted with an extremely sensitive issue.
On one hand, we must consider the cultural traditions and the significant, sustainable contribution, in some states like my own, of gaming to society through education, culture, and sport.
On the other hand, we must combat crime linked to gambling and protect consumers, especially the most vulnerable, to prevent excessive or pathological gambling.
Therefore, I believe that in this area the principle of active subsidiarity should prevail, based on cooperation between national administrations.

Nevertheless, we must be ambitious and advocate for the development of common rules and coordinated action against irregular online gambling operators that function without the necessary national licenses.
Likewise, we must guarantee transparency and enable non-discriminatory competition that pursues the public interest and consumer protection.
Finally, we must promote the formation of a network of national organizations that address problem gambling to facilitate the exchange of experience and proven practices.

The objectives of a sustainable common fisheries policy, the protection of the marine environment, and the promotion of fair competition in fishing are undermined if we do not vigorously combat illegal fishing.
The oceans know no borders, so efforts must be undertaken at both the European and international levels.

Therefore, the European Union must be credible in its policies and must sanction practices such as those recently published, in which vessels flying the flag of a member state operate illegally in waters protected by conservation measures.
The problem of illegal fishing is not only a matter of vessels flying the flags of third countries, but also a problem for European operators.

Furthermore, we cannot move forward without a robust financial instrument that conditions access to public funds on the strict implementation of effective controls and adherence to all fishing regulations.

Mr. President, following the climate conferences held since nineteen ninety-five, it can be affirmed that, as they are conceived, they have led to failure.

Madam President, Commissioner, esteemed colleagues, we know that without young people there is no future, and we also have the certainty that with high rates of youth unemployment, Europe can be unsustainable.

Mr. President, in addition to the eighty million poor people we have discussed, there are an additional forty-three million individuals who have difficulty consuming animal proteins twice a week.

The situation continues to intensify, and this is precisely not the best time for the European Union to implement budgetary cuts in food aid for the next financial perspective period.
