With regard to this, and to force an agreement with the Council of Ministers and this Parliament to allow the preservation of aid for the most vulnerable beyond that date.
Thanks to European assistance, food banks have performed remarkable social work, which should not be paralyzed by the selfishness of some governments.
That work has benefited thirteen million people, and thanks to it, with minimal effort, we have managed to make the common agricultural policy somewhat more significant.

The regulation we are debating today is not perfect. It cannot, on its own, fix the problems of a sector with structural issues and, also, given the economic context we are experiencing, with cyclical problems.
But this Regulation, though not perfect, is a step forward, resolute and in the right direction.

Because if, in recent times, we have all realized that there is no perfect market, it was very necessary to introduce into this framework—where we are also dealing with the food security of the people—all possible elements of regulation and protection for our producers.

It was very necessary that we permit the mandatory nature of contracts with a minimum and maximum term, at least as an instrument of defense, because, of course, our producers do not begin with the same negotiating strength vis-à-vis distribution, intermediaries, or collectors.
There are still many things to do.
We must improve safety nets and make them more agile and more effective.
We must prioritize further integration of the sector within the value chain, ensure that there is no quota allocation, particularly in certain areas, or promote the quality policy.

But, without any doubt, with our positive vote and with all that remains to be done, today many farmers can see this Parliament that has defended their labor rights, the most basic of all, which is the right to live with dignity from the income of their work.
B. has accurately pointed out the disastrous consequences that the approval of this Agreement would entail.
Because this agreement, which expands quotas for certain fruits and vegetables when the figures of the present agreement are not respected, is absolutely senseless.

It is worth noting that the Spanish Federation of Fruit and Vegetable Producers and Exporters reported to the Committee on Petitions, of this Parliament itself, the massive entry of tomatoes through Perpignan at a price below that stipulated in the Agreement.
Illegal situations such as the one described place the European farmer at a competitive disadvantage.
It should also be added that our farmers must adhere to rigorous environmental and social quality standards that our Moroccan partners do not always respect.
To conclude, I will point out the question of the Sahara.
According to the United Nations Charter, the Sahara is an autonomous territory and the exploitation of its resources should directly benefit the local population.
Furthermore, it constitutes a zone over which the United Nations does not recognize the sovereignty of the Kingdom of Morocco.
From the European Union, it is necessary to ensure compliance with international law.

I am in favor of an agreement with Morocco, an agreement that establishes rigorous control mechanisms from the European Union regarding quotas and prices, an agreement that combats dumping, that does not exploit the Moroccan farmer, and, above all, that dignifies our European farmers.
It is not, of course, this agreement.

Last year, the European Parliament’s Committee on Petitions requested that the European Commission amend the pricing system for the entry of fruits and vegetables into the Union, a system that is facilitating the fraudulent entry of products from third countries, as stated by the Union’s Anti-Fraud Office, OLAF.
primarily they are Moroccan tomatoes.
The same request has been echoed in a declaration signed last year by the governments of Spain, France, and Italy.

This, this fraud, is resolved by modifying the Implementing Regulations of the Common Organisation of Markets in Agricultural Products, because aligning the Customs Code does not resolve the problem, Commissioner.

For several years, I have advocated within the Popular Party the need to halt new concessions to Morocco until the European Union equips itself with the necessary instruments to guarantee the fulfillment of the current Agreement.
The European Commission argues that it is the Member States who must guarantee control over imports.

However, what the Commission fails to mention is that the entry price system is in effect, and this system prevents national customs authorities from accurately tracing the prices declared by importers to verify the absence of irregularities.

Amend the Implementing Regulation of the Common Organisation of Markets for agricultural products, and we will have resolved part of the problem, because otherwise, the legal loophole in European legislation prevents national authorities from performing their duties correctly.
No notes. Again, dear colleagues, the debate about a summit.
Many have been held, all announced with great fanfare, attempting to create an anticipation that diminishes daily.
They are ceasing to be credible because they do not contribute to resolving the crisis.
Peaks at which the same agreements are reiterated time and again.

It should be known that as long as there is no progress in political union and in strengthening this Parliament and the executive power of the European Commission, summits will be repeated, but the economic crisis will worsen.
In telegraphic style, two ideas: the first, the need to insist that responsible solidarity and fulfillment of duties are the
materials with which Europe is built. Secondly, that the immediate utilization of unallocated structural funds be authorized.
These amounts could comfortably offset the unemployment figures for young European citizens.

Madam President, from the European Parliament, I wish today to pay tribute to all the women who, despite the considerable progress we have made since March 1911, when women took to the streets to demand the right to vote and improved working conditions, I believe that gender equality remains very distant.
Today, women can work without having to ask anyone's permission, but in many cases they continue to earn less than men for similar work, which is unacceptable.
It is also necessary to remember the women in rural areas whose work is ignored.
I believe another uncomfortable reality, but one that must continue to be denounced, is violence against women.

Already this year, there has been an excessive number of women murdered, not counting the serious threats from those who believe they have the right to inflict physical or psychological violence upon them.
It is time to say enough and to say it loud and clear.
From this Parliament, I reiterate my commitment to the European Protection Order for Victims and to the Victims’ Directive presented by the Commission, which, God willing, will be voted on next June.
We must also say, and I would like to reiterate, that motherhood remains an obstacle to women's advancement, and I believe this is a trend that should be changed.
I want to send a message of hope, and with many women, with the help of an increasing number of men, we must advance on the path of equal opportunities, rights, and also of responsibilities.
We have come a long way, but there is much left to do.
I must admit that I do not absolutely and deeply believe in quotas, but I have to tell you that something needs to be done, and I agree with it.
Many of my colleagues, and of course, with Mrs. Reding, for opening this debate and advancing this path so that women reclaim the place they deserve; you can count on my support.

Mr. President, at a juncture of economic crisis and budget cuts that is affecting public health and in which, as in the case of the community where I live, research centers such as Príncipe Felipe, specializing in diabetes, are being left without funding, this Resolution is more timely than ever; it is absolutely appropriate.

We need a common European strategy against diabetes, and we need a recommendation from the Council that tells Member States they must increase research, even with stem cells, that they must coordinate their results to optimize them, and that they must establish programs promoting healthy eating and lifestyle habits.

In sum, we must prioritize the health of individuals above all else, and in this case, investigating, coordinating, and implementing nationally coordinated programs led by the Commission and demanding results regarding diabetes is to guarantee the quality of life of Europeans and ensure their own lives.

If we dedicate more money to this, some will take a little longer to be reimbursed, but it is certain that those who currently have problems will experience a better quality of life, and we will, as States, as Council, and as Commission, be fulfilling one of our obligations, which is to safeguard the health of our citizens.
Mr. President, of the many matters that this debate raises, I would like to highlight that of the emissions trading market, a market that was born with flaws, certainly.
But today, the limitation of rights and the economic crisis have meant a drastic reduction in the price of carbon; that is to say, it is so low that polluting is cheap.
It is therefore urgent to reform the design of a policy on that market, because its deterioration threatens all green efforts, all of the European Union’s green policy.
If emission rights are not valued, it is incentivizing increased emissions. Polluting industries will not invest in new techniques, and worse still,
The funding of significant projects will be jeopardized, such as, for example, projects related to energy efficiency or carbon storage facilities.
This is the risk.
It falls to us, to the Commission, and to the Parliament to bring it about.
Mr. President, few asylum seekers are permanently resettled in Europe.
My country, Spain, has barely begun with the experience.
The cases, however, are of urgent need.
The deputies verified this firsthand during a visit to the Iraqi-Palestinian camps in Syria, as did the news we promptly received from Tunisia.
Another more institutional aspect is the balance of power between Parliament and the Council.
Our speaker, the valiant Ruiz Tavares. There are many good parliamentarians, but few with such tenacity as Ruiz.
Tavares has fought to ensure that the European Parliament retains the new powers acquired following the approval of the Treaty of Lisbon.
I cannot forget the sustained work carried out by UNHCR, without which success would also have been impossible.
UNHCR has made us all aware of the urgency of the report so that funds can be utilized as soon as possible, now that they are so urgently needed.
And finally, many thanks, Commissioner, and I hope we can also give you and your kind heart the satisfaction of moving the asylum package forward next month.

The European social model we so proudly boast of is not solely based on our pension, education, or healthcare systems, but also on a way of understanding the balance between employer and worker within companies.

The labor reform approved by the Spanish Government without dialogue and without consensus breaks with that social model and distances us from the objectives of the 2020 Strategy, both with regard to job creation and with regard to its quality.
Labor reform alone does not create employment; economic growth does.
What labor law does do is define under what conditions workers enter companies, under what conditions they remain in them, and under what conditions they leave them.

And with this reform, where eighty percent of workers will be left unprotected because they will not be covered by collective bargaining agreements, where they can be dismissed due to a decrease in company revenue.

which they may unilaterally modify their schedules, what remains clear is that workers will enter the labor market with greater precariousness, remain in it with more fear, and leave it with less compensation.

Therefore, this reform, which undermines the European social model and prioritizes the competitiveness of the Spanish economy solely in relation to workers’ conditions, deserves a general strike such as the one being called tomorrow in Spain in defense of this social model.

Mr. President, Mr. Barroso, please allow me to state that the Spanish delegation of the European People's Party considers your proposals correct and supports both packages presented today, both the labor package and the solidarity aid to Greece, which is closely linked to the coherence of your approach.
It is undeniable, ladies and gentlemen, that we are living through difficult times, and events daily remind us that the crisis is still far from being resolved.
Attention has inevitably shifted back to Spain.
Unjustified alarms have been triggered in the markets, partly fueled by statements, in my opinion, Mr. President, that were untimely.
some, within the context of significant elections in which each contender cites my country as a dialectical element of confrontation.
Certainly, we do not appreciate any of the references.
On the other hand, some, to deflect attention from their own problems, also concern themselves with us in a less than politically delicate manner.
Today, here either, some have been with Finnish people, as Italians would say, and there has been some lack of political delicacy.
Honorable members, the state of the markets does not reflect the strength of Spain.
We are a solvent country with full capacity to meet our debts.
Spanish debt remains below the European Union average, and the Spanish Government is fully committed to meeting the deficit targets agreed upon with the European Union.
Never, gentlemen of Bogotá, has Mr. Rajoy stated that he cannot meet the objectives set by the European Union.
he said the complete opposite of what he is willing to fulfill all and each of those objectives, and he reiterates it every day.

The Government of Spain, in the few months it has been at the helm of the Executive, has adopted and will continue to adopt ambitious measures to guarantee fiscal consolidation and lay the foundations for improvements in competitiveness, job creation, and growth.
The IMF's projections, incidentally, the IMF itself acknowledges yesterday, predate the analysis of the decisions and measures taken by the Spanish Government currently.

Other measures that we, within the general state budgets for two thousand twelve, have adopted—which, in our judgment, will guarantee this year that the deficit objective is met—are this month’s Organic Law on Budgetary Stability.

It will present a reform in education and healthcare that will entail an adjustment of zero million euros. The reform of the financial sector will also undoubtedly contribute to financial institutions having to allocate over fifty zero million.
In summary, Spain is meeting the objectives set by the Union and the Commission, and what we are requesting is responsibility from everyone.

It is necessary that we all save ourselves, and Spain with all, without any doubt, and the criticisms of some or others contribute nothing. Either we are all countries capable of being together and contributing to growth and a new path, or, naturally, it will be difficult for us to move forward in the terms outlined by the Commission.
Mr. Romeva, do you wish to make Mr. Rajoy, the Prime Minister, the central figure?
That sounds good to me; I would have no objection.
But Mr. Rajoy is not the protagonist of the crisis.

The protagonist of the crisis is the inheritance received by the Spanish socialist, communist, and green left, which has left the worst inheritance ever left by any government, when they received the best inheritance any government has ever had.
Mr. President, this morning I read in a prominent German newspaper the news that Spain and Argentina have a conflict related to an oil company.
This is precisely the wrong way to frame the issue.
The conflict is between Europe and Argentina, and beyond that, with that significant European value which is legal certainty and its respect in international commercial relations.
European institutions have excellent legal experts who can find the appropriate instruments in original or derived Community law to neutralize the arbitrary actions of Argentine authorities.
I am a modest professor of Public Law and offer my services to them.
The credibility of the European Union before its citizens is currently at stake.

Mr. President, from the Committee on Agriculture, we share the ultimate objective of this Directive, to attempt to guide, through fiscal imposition, the composition of our energy mixes. However, we are faced with a very complex debate.

Full of sharp edges in the economic, social, and environmental realms—it is important to maintain those balances that will allow us to advance further in the environmental sphere, yes, but that will also not harm us economically and will not create greater social crises than those we are already experiencing.
This is the case of agriculture.

As everyone knows, energy costs are increasingly representing a very significant portion of the fixed costs of our agricultural operations, at a time when we are also engaged in a debate that combines commodity market crises with a perspective of subsidies and an increase in health and environmental demands that narrow profit margins.
Therefore, we have primarily requested two things.

The first is the maintenance of zero-rate deductions in the energy component, linked now to the drafting and compliance with energy efficiency and savings strategies in rural areas, and the incorporation of the
agriculture within sectors considered to be at risk of carbon leakage, in order to also access the deductions permitted within the CO2 emissions bracket.
That is to say, an environmentally more demanding policy, but one that maintains those balances that make our rural environment viable at a time of change and uncertainty within it.
We are experiencing a significant controversy that has austerity and growth as indispensable references.
If one hears the noise that is forming, it would seem that the idea of growth is a luminous invention of these days.
nothing further from reality.
In Europe, the pact precisely called the Stability and Growth Pact has been in effect since nineteen ninety-seven.

Therefore, a significant portion of the policies implemented by European institutions, such as those concerning regional cohesion and research, are policies geared towards growth and that pursue the development and well-being of citizens.

Therefore, and addressing the Commission and the members of this Parliament who have the greatest opportunity to be heard, there is no complexity on our part when engaging in that debate, a debate we can face with our heads held high.
In my opinion, this is a minority view among those who are not registered.
Madam President, allow me, first of all, to thank all my colleagues and, above all, the shadow rapporteurs for their assistance in this report, which has made it considerably more robust.

We all know that the twentieth anniversary of the launch of the single market is being celebrated, which must be the engine of economic activity and growth in Europe, key to overcoming the crisis and achieving the goals of Europe 2020.

Over these twenty years, the construction of the internal market must be made compatible with its development, with a broad framework for consumer protection, growth, and rights that generate dynamism.
and trust, transparency, a fundamental principle of democracy and good governance, which Commissioner Barnier referred to this afternoon, and cooperation between the Commission and Parliament.
It is now time to develop the regulatory framework relating to the protection and training of consumers, and particularly vulnerable consumers.
We know that the diversity of vulnerability situations, both endogenous and exogenous, complicates the adoption of a global legislative instrument.
This obligates us to address the problem of vulnerability from a cross-sectional analysis that takes into account the diverse needs, capabilities, and circumstances of consumers.
The Commission, being aware of current deficiencies, has focused its strategy on improving consumer information and education.
Being an ambitious proposal, it is not sufficient to protect vulnerable consumers, because their vulnerability stems precisely from their lack of assertiveness and understanding of the
information they receive, or the available options, or their lack of awareness of existing claims and redress systems, particularly in the case of cross-border and online consumption.

It is for all these reasons that, in order to address the shortcomings—that is, the problems—it is necessary to adopt a strategy of reinforcing vulnerable consumers and that both the Commission and the Member States incorporate specific measures into their legislation to guarantee adequate protection.

that goes beyond mere information, especially in those areas where a higher level of expertise is demonstrated and where the largest number of consumer complaints are registered—the financial sector—whose complexity means that, in principle, any consumer can become vulnerable.

Therefore, the financial services industry is requested to redouble its efforts to provide understandable, truthful information, expanding on clear explanations and using direct language regarding the nature of the products and services it offers. The food sector, in relation to advertising,

of foods high in fats, salts, and sugars, and to children and young people who are most susceptible to advertising for these foods; the transport sector, which often still faces difficulties when vulnerable individuals travel; and the energy and telecommunications sector.

where a lack of transparency can cause, in some cases, an additional difficulty for consumers, for example, in the energy sector when determining the tariff that best suits their needs, in access to justice, where consumers may encounter difficulties in accessing the mechanisms
resilient.
Therefore, the Commission and the Member States are requested, and allow me to issue a warning to the Spanish Minister for Justice, Mr. Gallardón, to not roll back rights.
and to move in a direction opposite to the tide of these times of difficulty, to put intelligence and good governance in favor of an alternative dispute resolution in consumer matters.

Finally, let me conclude that any one of us is susceptible to becoming a vulnerable consumer. Thank you very much, and I would like to express my gratitude to all the deputies for the assistance provided in strengthening this report.
Mr. President, Commissioner, the truth is that I have a feeling of despair, almost of frustration, that I must share with someone.
It will allow me to do so this afternoon with you.

This is the third or fourth debate we’ve had in this Chamber recently concerning the situation of youth unemployment across Europe, and debate after debate, while youth unemployment rates skyrocket in some Member States, we are nearing the

fifty of the active population rate, while many of them are already without any type of social or unemployment coverage, while all this is happening, while we transition from a situation that evolves from concerning to

Unsustainable and from the unsustainable to the dramatic. The Commission presents itself, once again, in this Parliament, in this Chamber, as if it were a political commentator, as if it were just another analyst, and not as the true Government of the Union, which it is and, moreover, is what we need.

Commissioner, governing is about setting priorities; governing is about setting priorities, taking the initiative, and furthermore, with the objective of achieving some goal, some objective, and furthermore, the Commission is not doing so.

Governing is not a simple restructuring of funds, nor even announcing such a restructuring to improve public perception; it is elevating an ambitious, enduring, and swift strategy to end youth unemployment.

Governing is not resigning oneself to a youth unemployment rate exceeding twenty percent and being satisfied with a pilot project of four million euros, which is ridiculous given the situation, given the magnitude of the problem we face.

Governing is not yielding to the pressures of the Board of Commissioners or other Member States of the Council who strive to convince us that from this financial crisis, this new wave of recession, we will only emerge by renouncing salaries, labor rights, or severance pay, that only a future of precariousness awaits us as a generation.

Because if this were true, furthermore, Commissioner, that we only achieve competitiveness through precariousness and that we will only become more competitive by being more precarious, then Zimbabwe would be the most competitive country, and it is not.
These are Sweden, Finland, and Denmark, which are precisely characterized by a model of exemplary relations and also a model of labor guarantees and rights.
Mr. President, employment is far more than a citizen's right; it is an instrument of connection to the system, an instrument of social integration.

Therefore, the more unemployment there is, the greater the political disaffection. That is why, Commissioner, I cannot accept your invoking matters of competition as an excuse for doing nothing regarding youth unemployment.

Because, furthermore, Commissioner, when it has been necessary to interpret the Treaties loosely to create, for example, the Financial Stability Fund, it has been done, and when the Treaties have had to be reformed to comply with or satisfy the delusions of a particular Member State regarding austerity, that too has been done.
Therefore, what is it that I want to tell you?
There you have it, for example, the guarantee of youth employment doesn’t require explanation.

Fight to increase the budget, utilizing, if necessary, the European Social Fund as an instrument, design a funded and solidarity-based implementation mechanism that most assists those with the highest unemployment rates, pressure to further change this policy of social asphyxiation for the countries that are suffering the most, and remember that behind each figure there is a person experiencing hardship.
Then, you’ll think like me that the crucial aspect isn’t who holds the responsibility, because for the citizenry as a whole, especially...
Madam President, Commissioner, I thank the INTA Committee for the work done, the rapporteurs, and the shadow rapporteurs.

Generally speaking, we are dealing with a good SGP regulation, necessary, specifically, in certain instances, for the control of import regulations for textile products that could harm the production of the European Union.
However, we are concerned about the exclusion, beginning in 2014, of certain countries classified as upper-middle income from the SGP, countries such as those in Latin America.
Because, what about these middle-income countries that have poorly diversified exports?
diversified. Why not introduce a diversification criterion into export strategy?
Because this could generate two speeds; countries like Costa Rica, Cuba, and Ecuador would benefit from it, differentiating themselves from potentially developed countries like China and Brazil.

Therefore, I believe we should support a period of transition, and that amendments will be presented with this period of transition to adapt to this situation for these countries and to provide the possibility of opening negotiations and trade agreements with them so that they can benefit from it.

Mr. President, I already supported the report by Ms. Nadelcheva when I was able to accompany her on the mission to the Congo, along with other parliamentarians, and indeed, I observed few villages with such a pronounced desire to embrace democracy and participate in it.
But a people, in order to believe in democracy, must also believe in their State and their Government, and that will not be possible solely through electoral support or external backing.
They also need a firm commitment in the fight against corruption and to break the indecent paradox of living in poverty in one of the world's resource-rich countries.

It must be said and denounced that a portion of the violence they experience is imported or, at the very least, encouraged by unscrupulous multinational corporations that, from Europe or other continents or states, are capable of engaging in corruption without regard for fostering conflicts over those resources to win favor with those who govern certain territories.

Therefore, Madam Aston, although it may not be your absolute purview, I do contend that a greater demand for traceability and transparency from multinational European companies and others from other continents that collaborate there would be as beneficial for the development of that people as the aid we can provide at an electoral and technical level.
Mr. President, to the speakers for the valuable work they have presented.
Colleagues, we are now debating package two, after having approved package six, after nearly all heads of state and of government agreed to two international treaties outside the established order.
community, after many other European regulations have created more community authorities for banking supervision, securities supervision, insurance supervision, and for systemic economic risk.
a proliferation of texts and more texts—reports, proposals—addressing new economic assessment criteria, new procedures, new processes.
procedures. We must not stop and implement what we already have approved.
Confronted with the instability facing the European continent, stability and legal certainty are precisely what is needed.
We do not require a patchwork of successive legal findings.
I don't know, dear colleagues, if I am dreaming.
The situation presented by the rescue is very concerning.
The full truth is not being told to Spanish citizens regarding the new debt, whereby the Spanish government and State are assuming private debt as public debt.
The Spanish Government has requested aid that it previously stated it did not want, presenting it ludicrously as a triumph, something a colleague in this debate had already warned.
There is no triumph, only failure, with Bankia and others.

I insist, there is no further politically correct approach for Europe than the one sponsored by the French government, behind which parliamentary ranks must coalesce, for we will not escape debt without a harmonious growth of all and the whole.

Supervision as requested in the two reports, certainly, all the supervision that is necessary, but essential concurrent growth, also anti-speculative, and also as alluded to in some of the measures in both reports and other reports as well.
Please, clarity and transparency as well, balance, as my colleague Sánchez Presedo was saying earlier.
Madam President, since I entered this Parliament, I have not ceased to denounce female genital mutilation.
that silent and accepted crime suffered by millions of women and girls worldwide—seventy million, I repeat, seventy million
An unbearable figure for anyone who pauses to study the terrible consequences of these practices, which hide behind the guise of psychological, health, or religious reasons—all of them false.

The truth is that ablation, practiced predominantly on girls of fourteen and even one year of age, can lead to death due to hemorrhagic collapse and, at best, cause and bring about severe psychological sequelae due to trauma.
From Europe, we must fight with all our strength to eradicate this violation of human rights, which undermines the right to equal opportunities and endangers health,
Ladies and gentlemen, this concerns abuse, cruelty, and torture against girls, and this degrading treatment also exists in Europe.
To this end, we must activate all the preventative mechanisms available to our legal system and I encourage our judges to act to prevent female genital mutilation.
of girls in Europe, punishing those who perpetrate it, that the law in Europe speaks with a single voice when it comes to combating mutilation on our soil.
Finally, I urge civil society and NGOs to actively engage in education and prevention campaigns.
Much road remains to be traveled, but many of us will not stop because we owe it to seventy million mutilated women.
Mr. President, Commissioner, I am fully aware that one of the reasons we approved the dairy package was precisely to adapt the sector to a market without milk quotas in 2015.

However, it is also true that each time this liberalization date approaches, uncertainty increases within the sector due to the lack of a clear exit strategy; similarly, the reasons why the sector demands prudence and reflection regarding the decision we face also increase.

Reasons, for example, such as the belief in maintaining vineyard planting rights or sugar quotas, at least until 2020, reasons such as the uncertainty that exists within the sector regarding the actual effects of the dairy package and whether

we will have had time to conduct a serious assessment of them and reasons, such as the uncertainty regarding the direction of the Common Agricultural Policy and, especially, its budget—that is, the portion of income that does not come from markets and affects our producers.

Therefore, what is it that we are asking you, Commissioner, to convey to Mr. Cholos? That we not implement a piecemeal policy of dismantling our protection system without a serious and rigorous analysis, because the effects on our producers are irreversible.

defer the quota deadline until 2015, until a date that provides security for the sector and opens a broad and transparent debate on regulatory mechanisms, because markets are still more unjust and producers are increasingly defenseless.
Mr. President, many members of this Parliament have listened to the voice of the citizenry, the voice of the streets.
Commissioner, you have said that this is an all-or-nothing agreement.
We members of this Parliament, too, have a responsibility regarding the affirmation or denial.
And we say no because this agreement produces confusion, as is evident.
Intellectual property rights and internet user rights are not clarified.
Internet users, are we concerned about intellectual property rights?
yes
Yes, it is an ACTA solution.
No, it is not a solution, because there are two issues to address—it is not a legal issue, but two political issues: a determination of the fight against counterfeiting and the
piracy and another new legislative framework for the digital environment, which we have repeatedly requested from the Socialist Group, we are requesting again.
It is your opportunity.
Do not turn your back on society, because tomorrow you will find that it is not there, and you will have no recourse.
Improve, this time it is necessary to accentuate the chaos.
The feeling of helplessness was of such magnitude that, by necessity, Europe had to react, and it has done so for the good of all, because the great winner of this past Summit has been the euro.
With this victory, hope has returned that Europe will emerge from its paralysis, transitioning from reflection to action.
In this summit, Ladies and Gentlemen, it was as necessary to adopt short-term measures to guarantee financial stability as long-term measures to address the deficiencies of the Union.
In this instance, the immediate was essential to continue working in favor of what was important.
It was imperative to launch a message stating that the euro is a common, irrevocable, and irreversible project.

We welcome, esteemed members, decisions as important as empowering the European Stability Mechanism to directly recapitalize banks, which will allow us to break the vicious circle between bank debt and sovereign debt—a thesis always defended, incidentally, by the current Spanish Government.
Furthermore, it will serve to intervene in markets in support of the public debt of countries that fulfill their commitments regarding public deficits and reforms.
Those were necessary decisions to guarantee financial stability, which must be, in the short term, the European Union’s utmost priority.
It is not this time, esteemed members, for certain countries to resort to nationalist rhetoric and erect obstacles.
I have already said it; it is time to bet on Europe.
Spain, esteemed members, is adopting and implementing in record time the most ambitious reform agenda of Spanish democracy, which includes a profound labor reform.
Furthermore, it is undertaking a financial reform based on complete transparency, and all of this demonstrates its commitment to fiscal consolidation and the fulfillment of deficit targets.

We also welcome the decision to launch a process toward greater economic integration through four pillars: a banking union, a fiscal union, a common economic policy framework, and strengthening democratic legitimacy.
Mr. President, ultimately, the Community, and subsequently the European Union, has always been not only about overcoming crises, but emerging strengthened from them.
I am pleased that we are once again going to succeed.
Dear colleagues, all our attention focused on banks, of which we repeatedly hear described as the lifeblood of society.
It is likely that this image is accurate, but we should keep in mind that every body is supported by a spine and joints.
Well then, the vertebral column and the joints of that social body we call Europe are precisely its transport networks and its energy infrastructures.
It is essential, as is being said this afternoon here in the chamber, to mobilize private funding and, where appropriate, public funding.
And, furthermore, it is an opportunity to promote the issuance of private debt, guaranteed by European institutions, specifically earmarked for these purposes, and open, in addition, to any investor.
Congratulations to the speakers for their work and also to the Commission for its clear impetus to these projects.

Mr. President, esteemed Commissioner, Minister, in which I greet the new Presidency, I am a veteran activist of the defunct Non-Aligned Movement that your country once led, and which fervently desires the territorial integrity of Cyprus in the face of military occupations.

Honorable members, it was necessary to seize the opportunity for a broader reform of the Tribunal, perhaps, but the Commission's and my colleague rapporteur's ambitions are very positive and should be supported with the unanimity they enjoyed in our Committee.
The agility and proper functioning of the Tribunal are fundamental, which I question with the newly delayed patent jurisdiction.
Congratulations to the opponent. Proceed with the reform of the Tribunal.

Mr. President, Commissioner Reding, my country has experienced too many setbacks since the People's Party came to power, repeated and continuous attempts to roll back established rights, such as silencing those who dissent, including consumer organizations.
The threat to Facua, infringing upon, among others, articles sixteen and seventeen of the Spanish Constitution by the Ministry of Ms. Mato, is a dangerous affront.

not only to freedom of expression and opinion, but also to the right to a high level of consumer protection, fundamental principles of democracy enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.
Therefore, I request that the Government of Mr. Rajoy rectify its transgression of illegally outlawing FACUA, and I make an appeal to the Commission to guarantee the protection of
protect the rights of Spanish consumers and act against the reduction of rights and the functions of consumer associations that the current Spanish Government intends to impose.
Madam President, Commissioner, first and foremost, I want to highlight the significant work of Ms. Macavan, the rapporteur, and also of the other shadow rapporteurs in reaching this point.
agreement at first reading, which was very important, since the regulations we had approved in two thousand ten came into effect and it was necessary to revise them.
not because the legislation was poor—the legislation was very good—but, as has been said, the recent events, known to all, occurred and demonstrated that there was a certain
a situation that needed to be rectified to prevent recurrence, and specific points of drug surveillance and security after commercialization needed to be strengthened.

Therefore, from now on, as has been stated, holders of a marketing authorization for a medicinal product who do not renew, withdraw, request the withdrawal of, or suspend the authorization will have the possibility of being authorized.
obligation to declare the actual reasons and grounds that have led to this withdrawal or the suspension of a medicine's authorization.
This is a significant achievement in the interest of transparency and will prevent the holder of a marketing authorization from attempting to conceal the true reasons for their decision.
Furthermore, in the event that any of these actions are carried out in a third country, all concerned Member States where this medicine is marketed must be informed.
Everything will improve transparency and security without unduly burdening the European Medicines Agency and national agencies.

The second significant modification achieved is that all authorized products subject to a post-authorization safety study will be automatically included in a list of products subject to this follow-up.
Finally, we must not forget that pharmacovigilance plays a fundamental role, and therefore, this plenary session should approve this proposal.
Mr. President, the agreement reached by the Parliament and the Council reflects what the involved Member States unanimously approved at the IMO.
These seas exhibit a concerning state in terms of acidification.
Furthermore, its regenerative capacity is very limited.
The mandated fuels are going to be more expensive, and therefore economic assistance for businesses is anticipated, which is quite reasonable.
But some colleagues have attempted to have the requirements for new fuels applied to all seas of the European Union as well.

We would encounter the paradox of a transboundary environmental problem in some European Union countries being resolved by creating a first-order economic problem in the Mediterranean, a region which does not share that specific issue but faces other environmental challenges whose costs are not intended to be borne by the rest of the countries.
The Treaty is very clear.
Sensitive areas must be protected.
But not all areas are equally sensitive.

Mr. President, I would like to once again express my gratitude to everyone who has made this Directive a reality, to the Secretariat, to the Commissioner, to the rapporteur, to all those I may have forgotten, and to all my colleagues who have stood with us.
I want to say to the victims, to all of them, absolutely all of them, without distinction, that for us, they and their families have faces, have names, are real, and precisely, in their name.

We will work to ensure that this Directive does not merely remain on paper, but, with the commitment and assistance of Commissioner Reding, which I absolutely do not doubt, achieves rapid and effective implementation, which is what we all expect and all
citizen.

I believe there are different groups of victims who would have wanted and continue to want a dedicated Directive, but I will tell you that the Directive we will vote on tomorrow does not forget any victim and, therefore, does not forget them either.
And I am certain that this is a first and important step, which will be followed by many other steps that will open those doors of justice that have been closed for too long for the victims.
When asked in my country what I do in Europe, I can say with great pride that I am legislating in favor of victims.
And that work, personally, deeply honors me and gives me great strength to continue working.

I am confident that, with support and commitment, not only from those of us working here in Europe, but also in our countries, we will, together and with the support of the honourable members, bring victims out of that unjust oblivion.

Mr. President, my colleague Turmes has done admirable work because, to push forward a regulation like this, the courage of this rapporteur was needed, who has skillfully neutralized numerous and cleverly arranged obstacles.
It has proven worthwhile because energy efficiency and savings are requirements of any energy policy worthy of the name.

We should commend important measures such as the requirement for the renovation of public buildings, the imposition of a percentage of accumulated energy savings on energy companies, and mandatory audits for large private enterprises.
However, the work of Turmes and the other rapporteurs will be of no avail if it is not accompanied by decisive action from the Member States.
An action that, in turn, must be accompanied by a firm commitment to these objectives on the part of the regions, the municipalities, and European citizens.
I wish to highlight the involvement of these latter.
Currently, what is observed is a great deal of frivolity among authorities and among citizens.
citizens. Don't we see, dear colleagues, in the harsh European winter people seated on heated street terraces?
Friend Turnes, we must not spare any effort to save energy.
One must commend the speaker, Iracha García, for the work she has done and congratulate ourselves on the agreement reached between the Parliament and the Council of Ministers.
It is a pity that the Council cannot join us tonight.
The new quality scheme for agricultural products entails a simplification of the system and a streamlining of existing authorization procedures, and that is good news.

Furthermore, it is a significant achievement that the obligation to use the community logo has been included for protected designations of origin and protected geographical indications, as this enhances the visibility of European products.
I also believe it is noteworthy that the provisions for the protection of quality appeals should be strengthened in bilateral agreements with third countries and a legal basis established for
to defend the logo of the European Union in those third countries, because I genuinely believe that the protection of European products in third countries must be an inalienable objective.

It's unfortunate that during the negotiation, this package was left a little underdeveloped, and it’s a shame, I say again, that the Council isn’t here to hear it, because the original quality package it proposed

The Commission has somewhat overlooked the commercial standards and the management of supply by the quality denominations of origin, detached from the Agreement and, as I say, leaving it a little hollow.
I believe it is regrettable that the Council has demonstrated such rigidity in these two matters, refusing to hear the positions of Parliament, which are reasonable.
The management of supply by appellations of origin should have been defended and will certainly be defended within the Common Organisation of Markets in Agricultural Products.

Mr. President, the trade agreement with Central America, Colombia, and Peru is an important agreement, and the safeguard clause—with the amendments we have presented—aims to be straightforward, efficient, and to provide assurances.

We have submitted amendments to protect European production in accordance with the Treaties and establish security mechanisms for both European production and production in the countries where the Agreement is established.
Protection of ultraperipheral zones is necessary because they are not diversified crops, due to the economic factor, because it affects a large number of.
More than ten thousand direct jobs and thirty-five thousand indirect jobs in Spain, in a population severely impacted by unemployment and its specific circumstances.
For example, the banana of the Canary Islands possesses a significant specificity in agriculture, culture, and gastronomy.

But it is also necessary there, where we are establishing the Agreement, in Central America, Colombia, and Peru, because trade is fundamental to development, and development entails labor rights, sustainability, and benefits for the producer.

Mr. President, the speaker’s work is very good, but I want to take this opportunity to say, within this framework, that our prose is very confusing, as anyone who approaches European legislation can observe.
We forget what Pufendorf already taught: that general laws should be few in number and their meaning must be correctly understood.
Therefore, those who promulgate it must employ all possible clarity.
And Montesquieu consistently insisted that legal language must be precise and concise.
That is to say, we must avoid esoteric jargon, replete with neologisms and unwarranted linguistic borrowings, because it generates a pernicious web where pitfalls lurk and arbitrariness takes root.
We address very complex matters in this Parliament, but it is our obligation to convey them to the citizenry in a comprehensible and accessible manner.
It is common for even legal professionals themselves—judges, lawyers—to become frustrated with our texts.
Good prose, dear colleagues, is the courtesy of the legislator and a way of demonstrating his respect for the citizen.
Mr. Deputy, I have just spent the time, the little time I had, insulting and denigrating from the most absolute ignorance.
ignorance. You know the Spanish Constitution.

What the Vice President, Mr. Vidal Cuadras, has stated is nothing more or less than the application of what is stipulated in the Spanish Constitution. Everything else consists of singular, personal observations that are completely irrelevant and which I can respect but disregard.

Mr. President, esteemed members, there exists an old principle that has passed from the legal sphere to the political one, and it is *pacta sunt servanda*, that is to say, agreements are to be fulfilled.
By this, I refer to the significant measures adopted by the European Council in June to address the crisis affecting us.

Since the adoption of these agreements, market pressure has eased, and these have been positively received – decisions that may break the vicious cycle between banks and sovereign debt, as well as plans to move towards a genuine economic and monetary union and a commitment to defend the euro irrevocably.
The European Council held last week, ladies and gentlemen, contains undeniable positive aspects; the conclusions regarding progress towards banking union are satisfactory.

The agreement among twenty-seven nations regarding the establishment of the banking supervisor is also positive. It is fitting that the implementation be entrusted to the Economics Ministers of the Eurozone.
but they will allow him to undertake a critical assessment of the biased interpretations that have been made of it, unilaterally.

It is not permissible, ladies and gentlemen, to make particular interpretations that may distort the mandate granted to the Ministers of Economy, nor do we applaud the recounting of matters as agreements that were never even discussed.
It is urgent to move towards a single supervisory mechanism that must cover all financial entities.
Furthermore, a common deposit guarantee scheme and a crisis resolution mechanism are needed.
The survival of the euro is linked to the urgent creation of an effective banking union.
Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the advantages of the internal market are undeniable: increased competition, expansion of the supply of products and services.
services, the creation of new jobs, more affordable prices for consumers, and greater protection—still not sufficient, and we cannot fall into complacency.
However, cultural, linguistic, protectionist, and bureaucratic barriers prevent citizens and businesses from fully benefiting from the single market.
A year and a half ago, we celebrated the presentation of the twelve priorities to stimulate growth and reinforce citizens' confidence in the internal market.
Unfortunately, an agreement has not yet been reached on the majority of proposals, as acknowledged by the Commission in last week's communication.

Distinguished members, Commissioner, the urgency of the crisis compels us to be ambitious, to go far beyond, and to reach agreements as soon as possible to foster growth, employment, and confidence among citizens and businesses in the single market.
Mr. President, I too would like to congratulate the speaker and the rest of my colleagues who have worked on this reform very adequately.

The financial crisis has intensified due to the existence of complex and unusual negotiable instruments linked to derivative instruments and off-exchange transactions, all with the aim of achieving high returns at rapid speed.
It is necessary to bring financial operations into a transparent market to guarantee the proper formation of prices and the competitiveness of negotiable products.
But, above all, it is essential that the information provided be comprehensible to investors, who must have full knowledge in order to freely consent to the risks they assume.
Transparency is of no avail if it is merely a brilliant flash of light while the configuration of negotiable products blinds the understanding of citizens.
I appreciate Mrs. Thyssen’s report because I believe that anything that strengthens the role and authority of this Parliament in political debate is moving in the right direction.
Far too often, we hear the accusation leveled against European institutions regarding their limited democratic quality.
This is a flippant statement that is not the occasion to enter into this debate.

Yes, to emphasize that this Parliament possesses the same legitimacy as any national Parliament and is even likely, with respect to some, to be governed by more transparent rules and, furthermore, to allow greater freedom to its members.
Therefore, all economic measures must pass the filter that this Parliament represents, both before their final approval and subsequently, when examining their execution and results.

The stability mechanism must appear before this House so that we, the deputies, can have exhaustive and firsthand information.
Mr. President, five point three percent of the active population works in the automotive sector.
The figures speak for themselves.
The decline in sales in the European market, coupled with the business strategy, means that, generally, companies are experiencing outsourcing and restructuring.
There is an overcapacity crisis currently affecting ten assembly plants and potentially a hundred thousand workers.

Unfortunately, there are few cases of restructuring with a long-term vision. Generally, a short-term perspective prevails, in which the primary element is gaining competitiveness through labor adjustments.

I have to tell you that on the same day Ford communicated the suspension of the GEN plant, the Valencia-based Ford company was also informed, in the same corporate communication, that its production would be relocated to Germany.

Therefore, we believe it to be a general problem of Europe; we believe that the creation of a legal framework at the European level is essential, one that anticipates changes and underscores the importance of social dialogue.
Social dialogue is fundamental.
Mr. President, today we are debating four reports that represent a revitalization of our common policy on security and defense.
It is a clear sign of the conviction that our security and defense have a distinct European dimension, in contrast to the minority Eurosceptic factions that also thrive in this Chamber.
The report by Mr. Dan Jan, whom I wish to thank for his spirit of seeking consensus during its preparation, contains significant contributions from the Socialist Group.
among others, references to effective multilateralism, the principle of the responsibility to protect, or the concept of human security.
We would like to see these aspects included in a possible revision of the European Defence Strategy.
We have also noted that a strong common policy on security and defense is also in the interest of our transatlantic alliance.
I must highlight another of the challenges that is acquiring significant dimensions for our global security.
it is the one on cybersecurity and cyber defense, a report that we also debated today and whose suggestions we hope will be included in the new European Cybersecurity Strategy.
In a context of severe economic and financial crisis in which Member States are being forced to cut their defense budgets, it is precisely when such European projects are most needed.
Therefore, it is more important than ever to strengthen the role of the European Defence Agency, which is being heavily challenged today.
I conclude by affirming that we can relaunch European security and defense, and do so with President Van Rompuy's project for the December 2013 Council.
Thank you very much to the four speakers.
Mr. President, Ladies and Gentlemen, once again, the defense of the general interests upheld by the Commission and the Parliament clashes with national egoisms entrenched in the Council.
Having previously accepted the legitimacy of both positions, achieving a balance is now unavoidable.
The relevance of the upcoming financial framework is undeniable.
The Spanish delegation of the EPP and I, on its behalf, reiterate that the Presidency’s proposal is, in our view, unacceptable.
A reduction of seventy-five billion euros on the already inevitably limited proposal from the European Commission is sterile and useless.
And it’s not just that—the new direct cutbacks to agricultural and cohesion policies represent crossing the red line that Spain indicated from the outset of the negotiations.
Esteemed colleagues, the time has passed for debating a purported dichotomy between austerity and growth.
Some of us are making proven efforts and sacrifices to correct the deficit.
But Spain, like so many other countries, needs to grow, increase economic activity, and create employment.
With this budget, one gets nowhere. On the contrary, it undermines the waterline.
Distinguished members, it is not possible to achieve a greater Europe with significantly fewer resources, and especially if those resources are distributed unfairly.

If that is the case, Spain will oppose a financial framework for the European Union that simply entails the disappearance of growth possibilities and, above all, any vestige of solidarity; and this is precisely the direction the European Council is taking.
Fortunately, this is not the path indicated by the Commission, to whom we owe thanks for their efforts in pointing out a different route.

And at this point, in the need for the Union, in the need for shared efforts, I want to thank Mr. Barroso for making a forceful statement interpreting the Treaties just the other day in Cádiz, regarding a purported secessionist within the Union.

He made it clear, unequivocally, as Guarantor of the Treaties, that if a part of a Member State separates as an independent State, it shall be considered a third country and, therefore, the declarations and effects of the Treaty itself shall not affect it in any way.

I hope, Mr. Vice President, in the absence of the President, that this can be recorded and that this secure and consistent doctrine of the Commission may continue to remain alive for the benefit of all.
